reviewText: I'm new to flight sims, I don't even have a flight stick. I tried this out bored one day and after about an hour of frustration, not even able to get the plane in the air, i stopped. However, a long while later, I decided to give it another shot. This time I took notes, studied, and really focused on learning the operation of the aircraft. Once i got the plane airborn from a cold start, i was hooked. This game is truley amazing. I've since got a flight stick, trackIR coming, all because of this game. It's my current favorite thing to do on a PC right now.\n\nIf your a sim veteran, you'll fit right in. If you are new like i was, give it a shot, but be patient. Take the time to learn properly and it's one of the most rewarding gaming experiences you will ever have.

reviewText: In order to understand what DCS World is, you must first understand what it isn't:  DCS is not a fighter combat game.  If that's what you're looking for, go download War Thunder; you'll  have hours of fun with it.  DCS is a high fidelity simulation geared towards pilots, sim-heads and plane geeks -- of which I am all three, therefore I absolutely adore it.  If you fall into that same category, go ahead and push the download button then come back to finish reading.  If, however, you're an average gamer looking to jump into a plane and start blowing away the bad guys, it's very likely that you'll be sorely disappointed with DCS.\n\nThe focus in DCS is realism, literally down to every switch, knob and light bulb.  The people who love this simulation crave detail, and it provides that in spades.  But you must love to fly.  I don't mean you glance at planes occasionally and think, That's cool."  I mean you have to be the sort of guy who spent hours and days and months as a little boy thumbing through books about planes
recommended: and generally absorbing every detail you could.  You skipped meals and let your rent run late as a young adult so you could afford your next lesson in a beat-up old 152 at the local asphalt strip.  You have strong opinions about the viability of the F-22 vis-a-vis the F-15 on a cost/return ratio.  In other words
hoursPlayed: you eat
voteText: sleep and breathe aircraft.\n\nDCS is a plane hobbyist's dream
helpfulPercent: and it is deliciously difficult
votesHelpful: providing an enormous feeling of accomplishment for every task:  cold starts
votesTotal: taxiing
votesFunny: take offs
commentsCount: radio navigation
column16: and landing are just a few examples.  The combat is simply the icing on the cake; the real object here is learning to fly the various aircraft in all their hyper-detailed glory:  cussing when you burn out the starter on the P-51 because you forgot to turn the fuel booster pump on; reveling in a successful crosswind landing on a short strip at dusk; setting up a clean Maverick attack and executing it perfectly then rolling off into a valley; or finding an airfield at the last possible moment and bringing a damaged bird in on fumes and prayers.\n\nI suppose you could use the arcade mode settings
column17: but I can't for the life of me imagine why you would choose to do so.  It would be missing the entire reason that DCS exists.  That's like buying a liter bike and putting training wheels on it.  There is no dynamic campaign
column20: (and thank God for that).  It's a simulator
column21: not a game.  The planes are the stars; the handful of pre-made missions are just there for when don't feel like creating your own.  Sometimes
column22: just flying a radnav loop above a thick overcast can be relaxing.\n\nAs for the individual aircraft modules
column23: I own a majority of them.  They are all uniformly excellent
column24: though you should stick to the aircraft which use the pro flight model and fully interactive cockpits.  Several of them
column25: such as the F-15 and Su-27
column26: are just ports from Lock-On; avoid those.  Of all the modules I own
column27: the F-86 is the one I keep coming back to time and again.  It has a special charm
column28: being at the leading edge in the early days of jet-vs-jet combat.  The sound is stunning (it sounds exactly like a real jet turbine; crank  up the surround sound)
column29: and the plane is easy to learn.  Note that when I say "easy
column30:
I've thousands of sim hours and hundreds of civ-av hours.  I adapted pretty quickly, but if you're new to realistic simulations, it will probably take you several hours just to figure out start-up, taxi and take-off.  Once learned, however, the plane rewards you quickly, with a feeling of speed unparalleled in simulations to date.  A dogfight versus a MiG-15 will give you an appreciation for the high speeds and energy envelopes involved, the enormous scope of the battle, and the difficulty of hitting a small, fast target with nothing but machine guns.  It's less a knife fight and more like a ballet -- if ballets were performed on salt flats in Formula One race cars.   Note that I recommend you start out by learning the art of jet-powered gun passes against an unarmed transport.  Practice that for several hours before moving  up to targets that shoot back.  Otherwise, you'll be watching that MiG from a parachute.

A couple other modules which stand out for their excellence are the MiG-21 and the UH-1 Huey.  I have reviewed the latter separately; search my review library.  They're all good, of course.  The best part is that you don't have to buy a single plane to get started:  the Su-25T and the TF-51D are included in the free download.  All you War Thunder mouse heroes, try the TF-51 and prepare to be humbled.  You just THINK you know how to fly.

As with any high fidelity simulation, I strongly recommend HOTAS equipment with rudder pedals, as well as TrackIR.  You'll have to spend some time setting up your controllers and tweaking your curves.  Accept this right now, or you'll get frustrated.  This is a program for adults, not impatient children.  Also, DCS provides excellent support for triple-monitor systems like Nvidia Surround, you're golden if you're a superwide or ultrawide resolution guy.

Hey, it's free; try it out.  Just set your expectations for what you're getting into.  If you're looking to be shooting down the Hun five minutes after the download completes, you'll almost certainly be wasting your time here.  But if you had internalized lifty-thrusty-draggy" by the age of 12 and are still willing to engage in a lengthy debate about the relative merits of the XB-70 Valkyrie program
column31: you'll adore DCS.  It was made just for you.  Welcome home."

Ok, so, many of you will discount my testimony knowing that I am an actual aviator with nearly 6000 hours, over half of which is in combat helicopters.

This simulation is the bomb! I just finished my first successful ground attack mission.  I've never felt a better sense of accomplishment after a computer game than when I taxiied to the parking ramp, shut down, got out of my P51D Mustang, and walked around to look at all her bullet holes suffered as we took out the entire platoon of BMPs.

Just take your time to set up the controls, learn to use the views, and learn to fly the aircraft smoothly and safely before you start taking on harder tasks.  The reward is definitely worth the commitment.

reviewText:
DCS World or Digital Combat Simulator is one of the best military flight simulators out. I have played for over 700 hours(this only includes DCS flight time, I've played Lock on 1.0 and FC1 for 500 hours too) and I don't get bored of the series. There is a variety of aircraft and helicopters that are currently out as modules to the game which are sold seperatly. I have all the module and have tried out each and every one. The DCS modules include the A-10C, P-51D, KA-50, UH-1H Huey, MI-8 MTV2 Magnificent Eight and the TF-51D (Recon aircraft, which comes free with DCS world).

Every DCS module has amazing detail and requires you to study on how the aircraft start up and how the aircraft functions. If you enjoy studying things before you try them out you will definetly love this sim. You can also just jump into the cockpit and mess about which is fun but the most fun is studying the sim and getting the aircraft up in the air, then the next step is employing the weapons which is even more fun. There is a module called Flaming Cliffs which is a good module for people who don't enjoy much of the study aspect of flight simulators and they can just jump in and hit a few keyboard buttons and get the plane started in less than 40 seconds.

The F-15C (New Update introduced the AFM (Advanced Flight Model) which makes the aircraft much more realistic), SU-27, SU-33, MIG-29A, MIG-29S are the flaming cliffs aircraft, these aircraft allow you to perform CAP (Combat Air Patrols), BARCAP (Barrier Combat Air Patrols) etc. Whilst the DCS: A-10C can be used for CAS (Close Air Support), FAC (Forward Air Controller) etc. Each aircraft in the game as shown above can perform various tasks but you also need to know the aircrafts limits in what roles it cannot perform, This will help you not get killed!

Overall, I Highly recommend this game if you enjoy military flight simulators and enjoy learning about how aircraft operate and how to use each aircraft weapons systems, Navigation systems etc. If you don't like the study aspect as said above you can just get the Flaming Cliffs DLC and hop into one of the faster jets and shoot some unlucky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ down.

reviewText:
This game, or more accurately, simulator, is one of the best games I have played in a VERY long time. No matter what your taste in aircraft or flying may be, there is fun to be had in DCS.

You can purchase aircraft from a wide number of time periods, from WWII, The Korean War, and even modern battlefields. There's also some very nice helicopters to purchase, but I can't comment on those, as I don't have any.. ;-;

If you like CAS, BVR, Dogfighting or just screwing around with friends in fast aircraft, DCS World is most certainly worth trying. The free aircraft you get, the SU-25T and TF-51 give you a pretty good feel for what you can expect in DCS, but I definitely reccomend picking up a full fidelty module if you like it, great fun learning what all the alarms mean... ._.

One quick note though, getting the game directly from the developers is a better choice than Steam, as the version from ED's site gives you earlier access to new modules, updates, and let's you buy modules from sales on ED's site AND Steam, which cannot be done with the Steam version ;D

tl;dr : BUY IT AND YOU CAN CRASH TOO :D
voteText: 145 of 163 people (89%) found this review helpful 9 people found this review funny

reviewText:
[I play the non-Steam version of DCS World in addition to the Steam version, so I have more time into it than my profile indicates :3 ]

First off, let me say that if you enjoy being able to jump right into a game and blow stuff up, DCS World is not for you.  If you only want to play with a keyboard and mouse, or even a controller, DCS World is not for you.  If you enjoy flying the C172 in FSX with arcade settings, DCS World is not for you.  If you want a SIMULATOR that will take time, practice, and a good set of controls to become somewhat decent at, then this may be exactly what you are looking for.

The free SU-25T that this game comes with is incredible.  The quality and attention to detail is beyond anything I have ever seen in a freeware aircraft for another simulator, and, frankly, in most payware ones as well.  I found it relatively easy to fly, and the controls were pretty simple after mapping most of them to my joystick.  The missions are decent, and even after purchasing a few DLCs I still find myself coming back to blow up some tanks in the SU-25T.

While purchasing DLCs is optional, you will definitely want to find a good joystick and throttle; the more buttons the better.  I have been using the Saitek X-55 Rhino HOTAS system and Pro Flight rudder pedals, and I still often wish I had more buttons for my  Ka-50.  TrackIR or something similar is also highly recommended.  Don't even try to play this with a keyboard and mouse - you'll save yourself a lot of frustration.

Most of the negative reviews here are complaining about the complexity of the game.  And honestly, I don't blame them.  Eagle Dynamics published a hard-cover, 534 page manual for the Ka-50 for $189.  But there is nothing more rewarding than actually putting the time in to learn how to fly it and knowing that if you ever had the chance to fly one in real life, you would know exactly how to do it.  The Air National Guard used the DCS A-10c to train pilots transitioning from the A-10a the the A-10c.  This is clearly not *just* a game.

Honestly, I'm not sure what else to say.  This is by far the best air combat simulator you will ever get your hands on outside of the military.  If you're serious about flight/air combat simulation, by all means download this.  Even if you're not sure, try it anyway; it's free.  Just please don't leave negative reviews because it's not an arcade flying game; that's not what it's supposed to be.

10/10

Sorry for being so serious :3

reviewText:
My Opinion: I could honestly say I love this game. It has such a realistic feel that not many flight simulators have. When I started I was just using the free modules, once I got hooked I started spending money on the game. The first module I bought was the UH-1H Huey and if you have ever played with it you will know how big of a learning curve there is. The Ka-50 is like flying with butter (it means its easy) unlike the Huey where you need to put the pedals and stick to a certain position so you can get into a good hover. If you ever look at the manuaIs for some of the aircraft it goes so indepth I feel like I'm acually studying to fly the thing. I love this game.

Prices: The prices for each module tell you what kind of experience you will get. In most cases cheap modules will give you a non-clickable cockpit and less functions. In most cases more expensive modules will give you a clickable cockpit more function. Each module is like a new game. It's pretty simple.

Bugs: The game has bugs like anyother. At this point I have been able to shrug them off and laugh at them. There are a couple screenshots on my profile of the bugs.

Conclusion: If you want a realistic military aircraft simulator, you dont mind spending money on modules, and you can be patient when learning a new aircraft this is probably the game for you.

Thank you for reading my review.

DCS is like math. I love it. It makes you cry. It wants to hurt you. You will despair of it. But every bit of success deeply satisfies you.

Eventually, you will succeed with something, perfectly hover with a helicopter, successfully land on an aircraft carrier. These are the moments that make up for all the crashes.

Like the feeling when you solved your first second-order differential equation..remember?

reviewText:
This game is amazing. Here's why:

1. I don't know how to fly an aircraft. This game made that clear very quickly.

reviewText:
It is a SIMULATOR, not arcade bs
If you like arcade shootout plane GAMES like war thunder with mouse aim, and have no experience on real simulators, don't waste your time and complain how bad the game is, it's a simulation, you need to know exactly what you are doing and spend time learning the basics of flying the plane!

Now, let's get to the point.
This thing is pretty much as real as it gets. you can control every aspect of planes in DCS just like they would work on a real plane. there are hundreds of actions and options that you need to learn, and when you figure out how to use different type of weapons for example, i find it really rewarding. it will take A LOT time to master this game (like every real simulator)

only negative thing I have to say about this, is that the in-game radio system doesn't always work properly in multiplayer, which really doesn't stop you from playing it, but it's a neat detail when you can communicate with the flight control and the ground crew like a real pilot would.

i really like DCS and recommend it to anyone interested in real flight simulators.

reviewText: Great game!  Very detailed!\n\nEach aircraft is like an entire different game.  You can spend dozens of hours learning and improving with each one.  Even the more 'simple' aircraft, like the ones included in the Flaming Cliffs 3 package have great depth.  The Steam community is very helpful and quick to come back with answers.  The in game training is hit or miss, some are interactive, some are just long videos, some more detailed than others.  To make up for any lack of training information is YouTube, a large community of players that upload training videos that can simplify or clarify many of the complexities of the game.  Online play can be great fun.  There is a division between the FC3 players, and the 'fully clickable' aircraft players (master race), but it is rarely an issue.  The developers are constantly updating the game, and new aircraft are added regularly, with many more on the horizon.  This game is very detailed, so if you are looking for an arcade shooter, look elsewhere.  If you grew up playing flight and combat sims, this is the next level.  Don't dismiss the free aircraft, they are very deep and useful.

reviewText:
An amazingly well done flight sim. Sure, if you're in reality a terrible pilot with bad habits it's going to be really hard to retrain yourself from the hand holding of other well known flight sims. Reality check #1, you can't expect to land at full speed. #2 Your 20, 000 pound Su-25 or A10 won't turn on a dime unless you know how to make the beast obey your wishes.#3 this is a very unforgiving and realistic sim. You WILL be shot down a hundred times before you learn to actually evade enemy fire.

Also, you really can't blame the developer for the user being too lazy to actually read the manual provided/available to each aircraft. I mean, if somebody's too lazy to read the mission briefing that describes the campaign progression why would you expect them to read the manual?

In conclusion this game isn't for the lazy or weak willed. It's for those that want the satisfaction of seeing an a10 at the local airshow and knowing you could start that sucker up and off the runway and navigate anywhere you want to go. While using any and all real world equipment in that airframe.

For me 10/10 for this high quality sim, DLCs as DCS definitely worth every penny

reviewText:
DCS World enables you to fly various modern aircraft or command ground forces in a hypothetical war between NATO and Russia on the Russia/Georgia border region. DCS World comes with the SU-25t which includes tutorials, multiplayer, a campaign, single missions and a mission editor. It's an entire game, for free!

The best part of DCS World is the ability to combine the various modules, DCS: A-10C and Combined arms for example. All the modules are linked through DCS World and therefore you can play on the same server as someone else flying/controlling different vehicles to you in one big battlespace! So if you fancy taking on a highly realistic combat simulation then pick up DCS A-10C for DCS World. If you want something a little more forgiving then you can grab hold of Flaming Cliffs A-10A.

More and more aircraft are being added all the time, with the F-15, F/A-18, MiG 29, SU-27 and SU-33 expected fairly soon. There are also sims for the Mi-8, Huey, KA-50 Black Shark and also the P-51D Mustang!

If you love aircraft and want to jump into something more true to life than 'Tom Clancy's H.A.W.X' then this is the product for you!

(Joystick with rudder function and some kind of head tracking system is highly recommended! Facetracknoir is free and works with any webcam)

Overall this game is fantastic if you are into modern aviation and don't mind a somewhat steep learning curve.


In case you were wondering (as others have) The reason steam thinks I have not spent any time AT ALL playing this game is because I use a non-steam shortcut to play it, the standard shortcut that steam provides does not work with the steam overlay for me. So before you start making clever remarks about how I know about the game, just bear that in mind :)

I get no benefit from having written this review, it is for your benefit so why would I lie about it? it's absurd lol. Some people eh?

reviewText:
Are you looking for a ultra realistic military flight simulator that includes fighter jets, CAS (close air support) jets, attack and transport helicopters and WW2 era fighter planes? If so then this game is for you!

The core game gives you the SU-25t Russian CAS jet and a WW2 era fighter plane with a fully interactive cockpit for free. To use more planes you have to buy them as a DLC but flamming cliffs 3 have cheap aircraft (check the store for more information on prices and aircrafts).

The physics are extremely accurate and realistic: E.G - missiles, fuel pods, bombs, airliners, wings, the nose etc - create drag depending on their size and mass as well as affecting the overall weight of the aircraft.

There is single-player training, free flight, scenarios and missions as well as the public and private multiplayer. There is too much for me to say about this game but I just don't have the time to write it all down, but I will tell you that the game has a learning curve for players who want to play this game.

Overall, if you love military aircraft, dogfighting and/or doing ground attack with aircraft with realistic simulation then this is the kind of game you WILL want to play!

reviewText: This is simply the greatest flight simulator that I have ever had the privelage to use. Through out three seperate installs I have logged over 200 hours and regret not one second. DCS offers unmatched realism, but not only is it realistic at being a simulator, it is fantastic at simulating what it is like to be a military pilot, this is what in my opionion sets DCS apart from all other simulators. I have noticed that many complain about the price of the module, trust me they are worth every penny, you will most likely spend somewhere north of three hours reading through the manuals, five hours practicing the procedures, at least twenty hours learning and perfecting techniques in that aircraft, and then countless hours enjoying yourself in the cockpit of a legendary fighter aircraft. You never will get screwed over by a low quality overpriced addon as you would in FSX or Xplane, as Eagle Dynamics is very picky about the content made for their game, they ensure you get a realistic flight model, a cockpit full of a bunch of buttons that each their own purpose, and a way to throw ayay a ridiculous amount of time. The SU-25 and TF-51 are not made to be permanent, they are meant to introduce you to the dynamics of the sim, I would reccomend buying the A-10 and spend some time in it and then decide that you love this game as the SU-25 and TF-51 are not an accurate reflection of what this game really is.

reviewText:
That feeling when I got my first muliplayer kill in the MiG-21, and with guns, is something I can't explain with words. And it was only an A-10C.


The satisfaction when, after tons of hours of practice, of mastering an airplane, its systems, weapons, etc, you get to use it properly and succeed, that kind of satisfaction I haven't experienced it in any other game, even when playing team vs team tournaments in tactical FPS games.


I can only say: if you are into flight simulation, into fighters, attack aircraft or helicopters, go for it. The simulation of most of the modules is superb.



Yes, I know it can get expensive, but actually I wouldn't recommend getting a lot of modules when starting. Get a module you think you will like and start invesing hours in it, and learning the aircraft and to be able to fly it as if you've been doing it for years. Then go to multiplayer and show what you are worth. First it will be all frustration, but after some time and experience, when you start acomplishing your objectives it will be extremely rewarding.



One last thing to say, and being an X-Plane 10 player I noticed really quickly, the clouds on this game are extremely optimized and look fantastic.

reviewText:
I`m with DCS World since its grandpa Flanker 2.0, I own all the modules and I put more than few months of playtime in to this simulator.

What will you get for free:

DCS World comes with Caucasus map and two free planes. The unarmed version of legendary WWII Mustang - the TF-51, and Russian twin-engine ground attack jet Su-25T.
The TF-51 comes with fully clickable/interactive cockpit - means you can move every button with your mouse.
The Su-25T does not have this feature but it comes with large variety of weapons.
I can safely say that both free planes (the TF-51 especially) are on pair with some pay-ware add-ons for other flightsims. The TF-51 model and flight dynamics are really amazing.
Free DCS also includes powerful map editor - you can create your own missions, scenarios or even whole campaigns.
Sim also allows you to play in MP with your friends.
Thanks to that you can get hours of entertainment with out paying anything extra.
Regarding the map - so far its still the same old Caucasus theater but its big enough for all those war birds.

What you can buy:
Various planes and helicopters called Modules" made by ED or third party companies
recommended: additional maps (currently Nevada terrain only) and expansion called Combined Arms that allows you to control many ground units and even atni-aircraft batteries.\nPlanes included in Flaming Cliffs pack does not have clickable cockpits and are more simplified
hoursPlayed: other modules are pretty much stand alone study sims. Those are not "cosmetic dlc planes" - every DCS module is a in depth replica of real aircraft/helicopter that was developed for more than a year
voteText: tested by real world pilots/ground crew
helpfulPercent: and mostly (like Huey helicopter) are licensed by their real life manufacturers. Every plane has excellent 3d model
votesHelpful:
in depth system simulation and flight model.
I see lots of confusion regarding module prices - you can go to official ED forums and see for yourself what those planes are made of.
After flying with all of them I can safely say - if you are serious flight simmer you wont regret purchasing any of them. DCS modules gives you months or even years of entertainment - I don't know many AAA games that can do that.
There are few aerodynamic flight models used in DCS World - less advanced and more professional ones - if you want familiarize yourself with details you can look up DCS wiki page. The most advance one Professional Flight Model (PFM) works pretty much as a virtual wind tunnel and its most realistic atm. To be honest planes that utilizes PFM feels just incredible

reviewText: First and foremost, I have to point out that I have much greater time invested in this game than what is indicated (55 hours). I've been playing some form of DCS since 2009 when I purchased LOMAC and Flaming Cliffs 2. I started out with LOMAC and progressed to FC2. Now I own several modules, including FC3. I didn't download DCS World on Steam until January of 2014. Prior to that I had DCS in its individual state. Now I have several modules: FC3, A-10C, P-51D, KA-50 and the free modules (SU-25T and TF-51). There are several different options in terms of modules and their respective level of simulation. There is survey level and study level. Survey level includes the SU-25T and the Flaming Cliffs modules. The cockpits aren't clickable and they have basic systems and start-up procedures. You can start an F-15C in 20 seconds by pressing RShift + L and R Alt +Home for the left engine and R ctrl + Home for the Right Engine. There you go, the plane is started. A study level module is much more complex and involves procedures almost identical to what you'd find at an air force base in terms of pre-launch/launch.  The cockpits are clickable and the weapons/systems usage are 98% spot on. The manual can be anywhere from 100-200 pages for the Flaming Cliffs and SU-25T modules and can be more than 600 pages for the study" level modules like the A-10C.\nThe learning curve for this game is somewhat steep
date: especially if you do not have any experience with any form of aircraft or prior simulations. If you're coming from games like War Thunder Simulation mode or Il-2
recommended: that will give you a good background so at least you're familiar with using an ADI or HSI

reviewText: This is probably the most realistic flight simulator out there (with the non FC3 aircraft). In this simulator it is no game, you have to learn how to fly, operate avionics, radios and weapons. Even though the learning curve for the advanced aircraft might seem big there are interactive tutorials that will teach you, which is better than reading some of the multi-hundred page manuals (which should be read when wanting to know how to operate something in the plane if the tutorial missed something). The world in this game is huge, mountains, ocean, towns/ cities. You can achieve long range flights with the map size. Also there is aireal refueling (only with the A-10C and most FC3 aircraft) which caters even more to long range flights. As some of you probably knew before you read this, that DCS is a combat simulator. So on top of having planes with realistic flight characteristics and avionics, you also have the ability to use that planes' weapons. The weapons are just as realistic as the planes, and yes, bombing with planes like F-86F is just as hard as it always was for the real pilots.\n\nThe only thing that is missing from DCS is more modern fighters that are not like FC3 aircraft, so far the A-10C is the only modern plane (but it is only a A/G aircraft) and from what I heard the F/A-18C is coming to DCS so hopefully it will expand the variety of planes and helicopters in the future

reviewText:
Easily the most realistic flight sim on the market. One below a full motion simulator, in my opinion.

This ultra high-fidelity simulator is great if you're experienced with flight simulators and basic physics and aerodynamics. (I recommend you understand how stalls work, G-limits on humands and the stress points of planes.)

With all but the most minute buttons modelled you can really mess up your flight if you want too, there is no hand-holding here. Can't stand the relative silence of the cockpit? Well that canopy can come off with just a click of a button or a flick of a switch.

----

While the base DCS World is fun it just doesn't compete with the DLC; the UH-1H Huey and MiG 21Bis are there for those of you who want a real challenge (The Huey is just a hard fly and the Fishbed is a rocket with wings attached and not a whole lot of fuel.)
If you just want a change of plane Flaming Cliffs 3 brings you the F-15 Eagle, A-10A, Su-27, Su-33, MiG-29A and MiG-29S; They don't come with clickable cockpits so they are a good fit for people who are transitioning from the Su-25.
If you're looking for a good transitioning point into the planes with clickable cockpits I recommend the A-10C featuring a fully clickable cockpit and relatively easy start-up.

----

Overall I (As an avid player of Flight Simulator X and X-Plane 10 and an overall flight simulator enthusiast)  recommend this game ONLY if you have a joystick and are prepared to buy DLC and other peripherals in the future. Don't expect DLC to be free, the complexity and time invested to make these modules is massive and you can easily put 100 hours into each module.

To play this flight simulator you are all but forced to have a joystick; it's a flight simulator, it's not a game.
I recommend your next purchase to be a TrackIR 5 or, if it has been fully released when you're reading this, maybe an Oculus Rift.
Finally, if you plan on flying the helicopters get a force-feedback joystick and RUDDER pedals, racing pedals with almost certainly not work and if they do they won't work nearly as well as genuine ones.


----

Recommended brands:
J: Saitek X52 Joystick
J: Thrustmaster Hotas Warthog (VERY expensive but VERY good.)
P: CH Pro Rudder Pedals
P: Saitek Pro Flight Combat Pedals
H: Oculus Rift
H: TrackIR5

(J:Joystick, P:Pedals, H:Head Tracking)

I've spent countless hours on this game, partially becuase steam doesnt count the hours for the actual launcher exe... XD But in all seriousness, this game is amazing. reviewText:
Probably the best modern flight sim on the market right now. The modelling of Air-to-Air missile performance is unfortunately quite simplistic (as are countermeasures), and high explosive bombs don't do much due to a lack of splash/fragmentation damage modelling, but the flight models and systems fidelity are superb. There's a reason DCS is a byword for high-fidelity simulation now.

Don't come into this expecting your experience flying Warthunder or whatever to translate, though. You must have a joystick of some sort, preferably with a twist axis (unless you own a set of rudder pedals) and a throttle (unless you have a proper HOTAS throttle). Knowledge of basic aerodynamic concepts is important, as is the ability to dilligently monitor your aircraft's systems for potential problems, and the ability to learn the limits of each aircraft you buy.

Luckily, you get two aircraft for free with the base game download. The Su-25T will teach you basic air to ground and missile avoidance techniques, while the TF-51 is basically the exact same aircraft as the paid P-51 module, minus the armament and a fuel tank in the fuselage that you'll leave empty most of the time anyway because it ♥♥♥♥s with aircraft performance. Get yourself a cheap stick and take some time to learn the free aircraft. If it tickles your fancy, buy whatever module interest you the most, and go from there.
voteText: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Let me start off by first saying this is not for the light hearted. If you come from a simulation background you will have no problems learning this sim. But if like me you started off without a clue or played the rare session of FSX you will have a lot of learning to do, even more if you do not know about military terms and equipment. This simulator is as real as it gets for most modules excluding the Flaming Cliffs add-ons. You definitely need a decent HOTAS system to be able to play, I recommend the Thrustmaster Hotas X which costs about £30 new and you can upgrade to a better system later on if you become addicted like I and many others have.

THIS IS NOT A DLC SYSTEM.
DCS world uses a modular system, you get the SU25T and the unarmed variant of the P-51D for free. The SU25T is an FC3 style module. This means that the plane and weapons systems handle as they would in real life but the cockpit is not clickable, you have to use a keyboard for most functions. Modules apart from FC3 modules are fully detailed with clickable cockpits. Alot of people complain about the prices of the modules but they are reasonably priced, if you think about the hundreds of hours of work and research required to make these modules then it is totally worth it. Modules range from the nimble and quick Gazelle helicopter to the flying pig that is the A10C to the old WW2 planes like the P-51D, this sim will cater to a broad range of audiences. I have bought the FC3 module because of its large amount of planes but I plan to buy the KA50 soon (reviews for those are separate). The SU25T is enough to get you into the fight.

GREAT COMMUNITY, GET TEAMSPEAK
DCS World sports a large and great community, several youtubers play DCS World and it’s not hard to bump into them online. If you don’t know what you are doing HOGGIT is a great place where there are people ready to teach you the ways of DCS. The unofficial Facebook group is also a great place to meet people and learn new things. Almost everyone is welcoming. The number of multiplayer servers is great with anywhere between 10 to 50 people online at once which can quickly turn into a mess if you do not communicate properly. One thing I must stress is the importance of teamwork and communication, TeamSpeak is a necessity if you are going online. It can help you survive a lot longer and reduces stress on other team members. Teamwork is key, sending CAS in without CAP is a recipe for disaster in PvP. The multiplayer caters for many styles, whether you want a quick session in PvE or a long campaign in PvP, you will love the many community made missions. These missions require a lot of structure, GCIs and flight leads are a vital aspect to success, so listen and communicate with them. The amount of times when the team is going for one objective and most of them are on TeamSpeak when a few loners outside of TeamSpeak refuse to help, losing the objective has been very low, even then I think they were new to the sim.

GRAPHICS AND SOUND IS GREAT
The graphics whilst a little outdated are great, tonnes of vehicles are modelled with great detail and the modules look fantastic. The ground can look dull at times but with DCS 2.5 coming out this is set to improve. The sound effects are very nice, listening to the RWR can drive you crazy at times but it is all very immersive. Watching your missile detach from your wing and hunt your target can be very entertaining and immersive. Watching your wingman breaking off to attack a target, then popping tonnes of flares as he turns with AAA unloading hell on him and the sky is breathtakingly spectacular, I have never seen anything like it in any game engine.

CONCLUSION
This sim is breath taking and very rewarding but frustrating at times. You might witness a few game crashes but all will be forgiven when you actually learn and enjoy it. The learning curve is steep and you will be destroyed if you jump straight in without reading or doing training missions, but the feeling of overwhelming joy when you destroy your first enemy in PvP is great. You don’t need to sink a lot of money into this sim, as I said a cheap HOTAS system will suffice and if you really want head tracking there are tonnes of cheaper alternatives to tracker IR which will give you generally the same experience.

Have fun and I hope to see you in the skies.

(THIS REVIEW WILL BE UPDATED AS TIME GOES ON)

reviewText:
The BEST flying sim EVER. havent played alot of flying sims but this one is best so far.  fully functional cockpits, manual startups, real weapon systems, its just amazing.  it can be as gamey or as sim like as u want. also being able to fly with people online makes it even more fun. reviewText:
Top-notch simulation platform.  I've been flying DCS since 2011, started with the KA-50, and it was exactly what I have always wanted in a flight sim: the full complexity of operating the flight, navigation, and weapons systems of a modern attack helicopter.  A-10C?  Same experience;  Highly detailed, fully-simulated flight, navigation, communication, sensor, and weapon systems.  This sim doesn't hold your hand and you get out of it exactly what you put into it.

For someone looking for a less-intense entrance into combat flight simulation, try DCS Flaming Cliffs 3.  The flight physics are a little more forgiving, and the systems complexity is greatly towned down, all while still maintaining realistic performance capabilities and excellent approximations of real-world detection capabilities and engagement envelopes.

I only have one word of warning to give:  Once you get a taste of DCS, you'll never be satisfied with the limited aircraft simulations" implemented in Battlefield
hoursPlayed: and similar games again."

reviewText:
(Notice, I play on the standalone DCS client don't let steam hours fool you) This game is my life, I've been playing it on the dcs standalone client for a year now. I own almost every module, no sim in history has ever came close to the detail of DCS. All negative comments about prices for modules or it being not user friendly is mute. This is a hardcore sim, if you love aviation then you will love this game. And it's slowly becoming the only true combat sim left for props.(Even though the ww2 aspect of the game is still very work in progress) IL-2 battle of stalingrad has went the wrong direction. IL-2 1946 is good, but the online community is dead, and the game has shown it's age. War thunder isn't even a flight sim, that games sim battles are a joke.
The only other good option is IL-2 cliffs of dover with team fusion mods, it mixes hardcore elements of engine management, but is more forgiving than DCS.

The module price in DCS is entirely justified by the quality done, if you can't see that, then you just don't understand what you're looking at. I recommend downloading the standalone client from the DCS website, you can benefit from both the steam sales and the companies own sales, which when they have them are HUGE discounts like 70% off.

If you are interested in this game, give the Su-25T a try, (It's free) it's one of my favorite aircraft still. And then bump up to FC3, if you manage to overcome the initial complexity of working the radar, then when you buy a full, entirely simulated module like the A-10C or MiG-21 then it will make life easier.

Though I NEVER recommend a beginner to pick up the a-10c, because even the more simplified FC3 aircraft are too much for a lot of people.

reviewText: Thumbs up!!! Thumbs up!!! Thumbs up!!! With more than 200 hours on record, I can definitely say I have experienced the ins and outs of this game, absolutely wonderful!! Best flight simulation ever, most realistic physics proven by real world pilots, most authentic flight dynamics and systems utilization. This is not a pick up and fly game, many hours can go into something as simple as effective weapons employment of one aircraft. But upon learning and getting to know the machine or machines of your choice, you will be rewarded with some of the best experiences ever. Eagle dynamics is wonderful, that lack a little in the steam support department, but online forums will be your best friend. I recommend to anybody willing to put some time into a game and learn it, and anybody who isn't satisfied with substandard flight simulators like x plane 10 and fsx, which are still great, but after you get your hands on Dcs, you'll never go back.

reviewText:
Lets start with what you get out of this. Two planes (as of 2014: P51 trainer, Su25T Frogfoot) for free. The TF 51 (P51 trainer) is the more in depth of the two planes and is not for the feint of heart but should give you an idea of what the level of realism you should expect out of many of these DCS modules. Currently, DCS A10C, Blackshark 2, UH1 Huey, MI8MTV2, P51 and (Millitary) all have in depth flight dynamics and controlls with a fully interactive cockpit.

Flaming Cliffs 3 is a module that comes with the F15C, MIG 29, Su27, Su33, Su25, and A10A. All of these aircraft have a slightly simplified flight model and do not have interactive cocpits. It should be noted though that this pack allows you to fly many different types of aircraft with the price of one module.

Pros-Epic, Realistic, Online community is pretty awesome, quality online players

Cons- Game engine can hold your system back (32 bit, runs on 2 cores, heavy on processor, only 1.5 gb ram), dated terraini detail, small community (though a quality one) Few aircraft choices, steam no longer supports serial numbers bought on DCS websight (steam serials are still supported by DCS standalone/nonsteam client though)

Realistically speaking, this game doesnt offer a whole lot in terms of aircraft count like some of the competition out there. However, the aircraft are extremely well detailed and handle exceptionally realistically. In a dying age of flight sims, DCS is still going strong, with some of the most realistic aircraft modeling around, with a persistent community and invovled developers.

reviewText: I really enjoy DCS World in VR but it took me a lot of effort.  This isn't specific to VR: flight sims generally take a lot of set up time.  I have a HOTAS with pedals and for each plane you have to map everything.  Fortunately once you have all of this completed after many rounds of testing the experience is pretty awesome.  In game the VR is amazing.  Head tracking is spot on and the cockpits are well done.  The VR user interface is fully capable but is not polished.  The traditional flatscreen interface is used in VR and you can't recenter in the game (that I have found).  If you want to experiment with flight sim then I highly recommend this.  The two planes you get for free deliver a lot of content (I have not purchased any DLC yet).

reviewText:
This is a well-designed and realistic game, and is a good choice for anyone who is interested in a realistic combat experience. The game has quite a steep learning curve, even for those who, like myself, are veterans of realistic combat and flight simulators, but once one learns how to handle the vehicles, and in particular the aircraft, it can be quite an enjoyable game to play.

My one major criticism of the game is its severely overpriced downloadable content, which totals at nearly $700 USD - much more expensive than the cost of both the base game and all the downloadable content of most paid games - and I sincerely hope that the publishers reduce the cost or sell it cheaper as a bundle, as I for one will not be paying $50 USD for one in-game helicopter or plane, among other ridiculously overpriced items.

In short, the game is very enjoyable if one enjoys realistic combat simulators, but I would not recommend anyone purchasing some of the downloadable content - which is ridiculously overpriced - unless Eagle Dynamics/The Fighter Collection reduce their cost.

Konan T-A Lim.
Sydney, Australia.
9/3/2016

reviewText: DCS World is without doubt, my favorite flight simulator. Even comparing it to flying aircraft in a game like Arma 2 or 3, would not do justice to the detail and realism DCS has. With this base game you get the Su-25T. It is no fighter, but a slow, capable ground attack aircraft with some big fire power. If realism is something you are always trying to find when flying aircraft in games, than this is the one for you.\n\nAnd, the best part of this game is that the base installment  is free.

reviewText:
Pros

Conclusion

reviewText:
[probably should mention that I own other DCS releases via stand alone (Black shark, Lock On II) and have recently expanded to Steam DCS ]

What can I say... except for this has to be the best combat based flight simulator I have ever known (and I have been doing flight sims since F-16 Falcon on the ATARI 1040st [old fart alert]). I have seen a lot of combat sims come and go but none have ever been; as well put together, well thought out, realistic, had such a wide scope of details and interaction, nor had such an easy to use and stable online facility. There is also a wide array of single player and campaign missions (if you are not up for online interaction). I also have to give a big thumbs up to the constantly expanding and updating choice of vehichles (helicopters,tanks,planes) that are being made available to us. (standalone DCS already has a large back catalogue of vehichles and these will inevitably find their way into the steam stores at some stage however, in the meantime there is already a large selection of well known favourites available).

I have to say that DCS world ticks all the box's,

1.flight charecteristics are amazing,

2.on board systems are detailed and relevant,

3.real world type damage that affects your planes abilities,

4.detailed weapons systems and management that actually get a bit of adrenaline pumping,

5.sound is fully imersive not to mention well balanced (no ear aches after prolongued play at full volume.)

6.Graphics are jaw droppingly stupendous whether inside the cockpit or outside the plane graphical detail is heart stopping as is the landscape and objects/buildings/mountains/sea/clouds/sun (and I am only running NVIDIA 750ti ! I would love to see it on one of the latest generation GPU's the mind boggles...)

I think the biggest tribute that I can pay to this simm is that: when I use air travel in the real world since DCS I know and can feel every thing the pilot is doing from take off to landing - though this can make for some nervous back seat driver feelings (He's retracting those flaps a little early for my liking..." "I SAY ! STEWARDESS Could I have a word with the pilot please...^^ [air marshall raises eyebrowes] ;)

Quite simply a 5 star release
[disclaimer] this is not an arcade title ! YOU WILL need to know about flight and if you don't... Well DCS will teach you :)"
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
anyone who has played lock on will recognise this title ... same makers ... and its all the better for it

now the free aircraft are great , well realised and fun , not much is as much fun as hopping into a tf51d mustang ... a p51 without guns and just barrelling around , then you start practicing landings and you see how the flight model works and changes subtly as you decelerate from 300 kts to 150 to land and taxiing with differential brakes , after this you'll spend an age learning how to cold start the engine and systems , and in spite of how heavy it sounds it draws you in ... after all a mustangs a damn sight more fun than a cessna

after that you can try the su25 ... the soviet answer to the a10 , again its deep but not so deep that you will never get the hang of it but hard enough that complete mastery is after many hours ... think 100+ before your targeting in low light and doing pop up attacks

now im no fan of the frogfoot but i enjoy deep sims so i splashed a bit of cash and got the a10c warthog package ... thats deep as in setting waypoints , radio frequencies , setting chaff/flare dispersions etc etc ... but its bloody good fun , its also fully configurable with a good flight stick , i have an old hotas cougar that i want to mod for this , but generally im using a saitek x52 ... also excellent for elite dangerous , in addition i use it with an oculus dk2 and quite frankly this transforms this from a game to serious immersion territory , i can blat around in my a10 looking out over the wings and scan all around and the sheer scale of the aircraft is there ... your looking right back down 40 foot of fuselage to the tail over the huge turbofans , then you see the weapons draped under the wings however you set its loadout ... its there in full effect , i may as well just join the usaf as im already there just without the BS side of things :)

another bird i had to get was the f15c , not as fully realised as the a10c but great fun , imagine full afterburner runs down the valleys keeping below 200 feet contrails streaming off the wings as you pull g then going vertical breaking through the clouds and looking down at a beautifully realised world ... when your machines good and you have the magic accessories this simulation really is as close to flying as you can get , i used to be an raf engineer and a part time glider pilot so i do understand whats being attempted here and you just cannot get better

and its free!!!! , you just chip in when its given you a taster of what the real military do

reviewText:
D(L)CS world is (quite obviously) a flight simulator game, and a really great one.

The game is hard, unforgiving, and requires a lot of practice to properly play, but once you figure out you're not supposed to end up with your nose in the ground it's a lot of fun.

It is important to note that, while the game itself is free, it's almost impossible to play properly without using a good flight stick (the T-flight HOTAS X by thrustmaster is a pretty good choice if you don't want to spend a load of money on the more advanced choices like the Thrustmaster Warthog or the saitek X-52) which adds some costs to playing.
DCS world comes free with the SU-25 frogfoot known by many from battlefield 4 and the TF51D (an unarmed version of the P51 Mustang used during WW2) but for different planes like the A10 you'll have to get the DLC.

TL;DR it's great if you don't mind to put some effort and money into it

reviewText:
If you are looking for a cerebral experience, this is it. Great niche community ages ranging from youngins' to actual pilots or crew chiefs online. So many videos for training, helpful forums and a huge update coming out soon 1.5 (hopefully!)   Didn't know anything about flying before this game, but after many sessions and beers, it grew on me. I can start the A10C manually in under 5 minutes now, including INS warmup. Highly recommended if you want a fun game that isn't mindless drull.
There are two types of cockpit layouts basically. Some aircraft modules have fully interactive cockpits. Others, have limited cockpits that utilyze hot keys. You get the modules that you want, and if you don't know or can't decide, watch a few videos online. Hell, the game is free and comes with two complimentary aircraft.
I have setup face tracking for this game. I built a three IR LED system for under $7, and there is a multitude of freeware out there to use. So stupid amazing. The game is also very mod friendly and allows rather easy export of .lua files to utilyze if you are building a sim pit. I have a few panels that I have already made.
As you can see, you can go easy and arcadey mode, or fully immersed experience. Enjoy!

reviewText:
In one sentence, this simulator is fatastically complex but simple enough for anyone to use (if they have the patience) and will provide hundreds of hours of gameplay.

I'd definitely recommend using some sort of HOTAS setup to play the game. I'm using a Saitek X-52 Pro which works well, but even with all the button mapping provided with it, I still find myself using the keyboard quite a lot to use certain systems such as the autopilot and with things like starting up the aircraft. I'd also recommend looking into TrackIR or another headtracking system, which will give you the full feel of flying the aircraft.

The training scenarios are very well thought out, especially for the SU-25T, which is included with the base game free of charge. The scenarios go through every possible system in the aircraft, from startup to navigation to landing to countermeasures.

The missions are fun yet difficult, which will make you want to run through them again and again. I've only successfuly completed a handful in the 10+ hours I've spent playing them. I haven't spent any time in multiplayer yet, but from what I've read and watched on the internet, it will be even better than single player.

If you like flying, I'd definetly recommend this. Plus, it's free ;)

reviewText:
In one sentence, this simulator is fatastically complex but simple enough for anyone to use (if they have the patience) and will provide hundreds of hours of gameplay.

I'd definitely recommend using some sort of HOTAS setup to play the game. I'm using a Saitek X-52 Pro which works well, but even with all the button mapping provided with it, I still find myself using the keyboard quite a lot to use certain systems such as the autopilot and with things like starting up the aircraft. I'd also recommend looking into TrackIR or another headtracking system, which will give you the full feel of flying the aircraft.

The training scenarios are very well thought out, especially for the SU-25T, which is included with the base game free of charge. The scenarios go through every possible system in the aircraft, from startup to navigation to landing to countermeasures.

The missions are fun yet difficult, which will make you want to run through them again and again. I've only successfuly completed a handful in the 10+ hours I've spent playing them. I haven't spent any time in multiplayer yet, but from what I've read and watched on the internet, it will be even better than single player.

If you like flying, I'd definetly recommend this. Plus, it's free ;)

reviewText:
I'll narrow this down to the good and the bad points about this game. (Updated 10/13/2015, shortly after graphics overhaul. [NOTE!] So far these upgrades are not shown in the above screenshots)

The Good:
-A large array of aircraft to fly(if you buy the moduls). Many of which are fully interactive, as in almost every switch and button can be flipped with the click of your mouse(you can rebind the keys as you see fit). The rest of the aircraft are more like simplifed simulations, not fully interactive but easier to learn. As far as I know, they handle realisticly.

-Amazing graphics post update! The lighting, weather, and smoke effects are absurdly good, the ground now uses a bump map, meaning flat textures on the ground cast shadows, it really makes the terrain look a million times better. Basically it just looks better and even runs better.

-Detailed single player campaigns for each and every aircraft, some single player campaigns very in their difficulty and legnth. For example, the A-10A's campaign features smaller scale misisons that don't require much time to complete. Where as the SU-25's campaign features much larger scale misisons that take much longer to complete(imagine after taking off from your airfield, you must fly for 20-30 minutes to the combat zone, then fly back to land when your mission is complete, Which I guess is more realistic).

-Quick misson generators which allow you to practice with your aircarft before doing the campaigns.

-One thing I really like is that you can choose your payload, each aircraft has a large variety of weaponry, and it is fun carefully choosing your payload according your mission objective. Variety is such a great thing, and variety is something this game has in large quantities.

-The game is very well optimized now, it used to run like garbage even with incredeble hardware, but even after the graphics overhaul, the game runs a lot more smoothly than it did.

-The load times have been vastly improved, it used to take 5 minutes to load anything up in this game, now its about 30 seconds to a minute to load. Any subsequent load time is around 15 seconds.

Bare in mind my hardware specs are as follows:
AMD 8-core 4.0 GHZ
R9 290 with 4GB of VRAM GDDR5
12GB 1600MHZ of RAM

The Bad:
-expect a minor frame rate dips if our have mirrors and ground clutter active.

-The game's training is hit or miss. The SU-25T(which you get for free) has training missions that are interactive. Then you have most of the Flaming cliffs 3 aircraft which have shoddy low res videos, that is out of sync with the sound and voice that is explaining everything. For the Mi-8, the game will only teach you how to turn it on, take off, and how to use the weapons, but it only tells you how to use the rockets, and 2 of the 3 types of gun pods, and doesn't teach you how to use bombs. Worst of all, it did not teach me how to land with the helicopter, which is harder than you may think. I crashed 40 times trying to figure out how to land properly. The game has a steep learning curve, and the training videos just makes an already hard to learn game even more inaccessible.

-I find that the default controles are confusing and clunky. I basically had to completely setup and rebind the contols to something more comfortable. This took a lot of time, learning what each function did, then figuring out what my new layout should be. But when your done, your done and can enjoy the game. Keep in mind, you have to completely set up your controles for each indavidual vehicle!

In conclusion:
If I can add anything more to the review, I will. But overall, the game is great, and I highly reccomend it if you like flight simulators.

reviewText: This game is the reason I got into flight simulation!After watching about 100 videos of people playing & learning to fly in DCS, I bought an X55 Rhino, Oculus Rift DK2, a leather drivers-seat from an old Subaru, mounted in a simple pine frame... 6 months later, and I think I've only scratched the surface of what this game can show me... I've taken my setup 100's of km to demo to my workmates, family, & friends, most are simply breath-taken with what they experience (the rest get sick from VR ;) ).\nIf you want to know what it's like to fly a real plane, but can't afford lessons, this is probably the closest you're going to get for at least the next decade... I can't recommend this game enough... buy it!... scratch that... fly the Su-25T & TF-51D for free... then buy it!

reviewText:
EDIT: August 2015. DCS World has really grown on me. The simulation of airplanes by third parties is very well done, even with some of them still in beta. Eagle Dynamics also has a great idea shifting the burden of module development onto third parties for the most part, allowing them to commit more manpower to features, engine upgrades, and other things we have yet to learn about. The World War 2 planes, while few in number (P-51, BF-109K-4, and FW-190D-9) are well made, and a blast to fly.

Integrates seamlessly with the Tacview software so you can review flights later on in a similar way Red Flag debriefings are handled.

You will need a decent flight stick, one with throttle control. The learning curve is steep. If you want to get the full experience, expect to spend a few hours learning how to start your particular aircraft, operate it's various systems, how it handles, optimum turning speeds, and how to evade missiles. If you stick with it, the payoff is very worth it.

reviewText:
I played the standalone version before playing the steam version so have more hours ingame than steam says.

DCS World is a fantastic simulator, but please note the sim part of the name... this isn't a game you are going to load up and be flying around like Maverick within the first 2 minutes.  If you are willing to learn how the planes handle, learn what the limitations on each plane/weapon/vehicle are and practice, practice and more practice then DCS World is an amazing experience and game.

The two planes that come with the free version are perfect for learning how to fly, the DLC modules bring in more challenging planes, maps and campaigns.

The free map in the Black Sea region is huge, with more than enough land mass and sea area.

Work is constantly being done on the sim aswell to keep the graphics and sound up to date, the new 2.0 update in testing at the moment is fantastic looking.

The free single player campaign for the SU-25T is interesting, the tutorials are informative and the included mission editor is easy to use and gives you the ability to create very advanced missions and campaigns.  Multiplayer is also an amazing experience.

I'ld recommend DCS World to anyone with an interest in flight from both modern and WWII eras, even if all you want to do is experience flying and not interested in combat.

reviewText:
Keen on reading pages after pages of manuals on radar systems, auto pilots, flight controlls and what not?
Feel the urge to be shot down time after time again by enemy SAM stations and fighters?
Do you have a desperate need to struggle with control mapping, button possitioning and horrible flying weather?

If yes, continue reading. If no, move on.

Because if you get past all of the earlier mentioned struggles and frustrations this simulator is fantastically rewarding!
The feeling you get when you land your first bombing run spot on or shoot down your first enemy fighter with a AMRAM missile is absolutely superb! If you choose to put in the hours requiered, this simulator is absolutely breathtaking!

Do keep in mind that this is a simulator much more than it is a game. Therefore it is not for those who is not willing to lay down the time and effort to get it just right. Furter more you ABSOLUTELY need a joystick and throttle. Preferably a seperated joystick, throttle and peddals. I use the Thrustmaster HOTAS Warthog setup along side the Saitek PRO rudder pedals, and this works wonderfully.

I am curently awaiting my Oculus Rift and can not wait to pair it up with this sim!

reviewText:
As far as old school simulator games go, there are still plenty of them going around, still alive by the modding community or it's general community at all. Among these was the pretty 'out of the blue' Lock On - Modern Air Combat, or as we called it back then - LOMAC. Amazing graphics, systems, physics, mechanics, it was a breeze of fresh air, no more we needed the piston planes simulation to sane it, we finally moved on to the modern battlefield.

DCS World recaptures that sensation, and then amplifies it several times, and it's making it even bigger and better, with new modules, new mechanics, new looks and soon enough - a whole new engine, which will run smoothly and beautifully.

Even if the modules are a bit on the pricey, i can't recommend it enough, buy just ONE module, pick one, MiG-21, A-10C, Flaming Cliffs 3, whatever you choose, you'll feel you're buying something WORTH.

This is where we, lovers of speed, smoke, and fire, can reunite and rejoice.

reviewText:
An absolutely incredible simulator that's improving all the time. Be warned though, this is not for casual pilots (i.e. the War Thunder or Ace Combat crowd). It's not a pick-up-and-play game. This is an ultra realistic sim, and the learning curve is steep. You'll find that most of the negative reviews of this sim come from people who were expecting something far less realistic that could be played with an gamepad. A HOTAS joystick & throttle setup is pretty much essential.

There are currently six different third party developers developing aircraft modules for DCSW, so there are always new aircraft from many different eras of aviation on the way. The future for DCSW is a bright one.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
DCS World: a great flying simulator, and it's FREE!
I'll write down a fast review, because I haven't got much time to spend on this.

I'm playing this game as my main flight sim. Is the game fun at the beginning? No, not really. At the start it was just frustrating. The commands are hard to learn, and not intuitive. I couldn't turn on the plane.
Then I got it, and started playing. I liked it. So I went to the store and bought a flying joystick.
Logitech Attack 3(fun fact: I bought it for CHF 5.- (€5 circa) NEW!)
I bought the F-15C Eagle too. (not fun fact: I bought it and the same day it went 50% off. ♥♥♥♥ my life)
It's a really good game, the physics are really realistic and playing with friends is fun! Formation flying and dogfights are really satisfying.

Pros and cons
Pros:
-good graphics
-good planes
-good dedicated servers and community
-physics are good!

Cons:
-learning curve
-a really hard flight sim, don't bother downloading îf you're not looking over to spend time on learning how to fly a plane

Final rating:Well, I rate it 9/10 'cause it's a really good game overall.

AS I SAID, let go of this game if you're not gonna spend time learning how to do it. It's not install&shoot. NOT. AN ARCADE. GAME.
I've seen negative reviews saying too realistic". Dumbasses downloading a flight SIMULATOR and whining about it being what it is supposed to be.

reviewText:
If you like your flight sims then this is a must have. Whether it's from a easy to use SU-25T or the hightly detailed A-10C there is something that is in here to impress any aircraft enthusist. The free SU-25T may seem like a mediocre aircraft but it does play an important role. I still fly it and I have both A-10 and FC3. The SU-25 is the only aircraft that can effectily provide SEAD (Supression of Enemy Air Defences) like SAMs and AAA.

It does take a bit of time to set up to the way you want. Playing around with modifiers and keys for controls can be a tedious task but all worth it. You also need a mid-range PC to run it, if you want to risk running it on your girlfriends laptop I've got bad news for you...
DCS World and it's modules provide an as good as it gets simulation. Definately do not pass up the oppotunity to learn about the world of modern air combat.

reviewText: A great simulator, however, not for the feint of heart. If you are looking for an Ace Combat style game, look elsewhere. The learning curve on this game is large. Whereas most games have a 1-3 hour learning curve to be proficient, 2-3 weeks is to be expected here. The effort is, however, greatly rewarded. With time and effort, and a pinch of anger management, you get a truly immersive experience. As far as DLC is concerned, that is where this game truly shows its colors. They can be a bit pricey, ranging from $10 to $40. It is well worth the cost, and the game is in no way diminished by purchasing a single or select few items as opposed to all. All in all, I cannot recommend this game enough for real world pilots and enthusiasts alike.

reviewText:
Best flight sim on the market. It's really realistic, so it may be quite hard for new players. Don't download it if you expect something like War Thunder with F-16. If you really like having a less - arcade, realistic experience, and you have some patience, you will learn really fast.
Devs put a lot of time and effort in every module (which have clickable cockpits), so there are only few planes at the moment, but there are multiple dev groups. There are 2 types of modules (DLCs):

---  Very realistic, with clickable cockpits (everything is funcinal just like in real-life): A-10C, KA-50, UH-1H, MI-8, MIG-21, P-51, BF-109, Fw 190D-9, F-86, C-101 Aviojet, Hawk T.1A - some of them are in Beta (as for now), but even those have a lot of features already (A-10C, KA-50 and UH-1 are 100% complete), also there should be F-15 and F-18 soon

--- Other modules are from Flaming Cliffs 3 which is like more arcade version of DCS, but has DCS engine and absolutely compatible. Those FC3 planes are not clickable, so they have less realistic features (you don't have to press 40 buttons to start up, just push 4 buttons on keyboard, wait 10 sec and it's on), but it's still enjoyable especially for new players.
DCS is free but it has only 2 free modules - SU25-T and TF-51D. SU-25 doesn't have clickable cockpit, but it still has many features - weapons, autopilot, radar and stuff, and TF-51D is fully clickable (but doesn't have any guns)
Some DLCs have manuals, but even if they don't, just go on Youtube or Google. You can also use manuals for real aircraft, those have a lot of pages but they worth it.

Multiplayer has a lot of servers but only few have more than 10 players.

The downsides of the game - those are quite random but common.
- FPS - i'm running the game with Radeon HD7950 (overlocked, equal to GTX770), sometimes getting 25-30 fps on low-medium settings - when on airfield, near some big town, or in multiplayer. But usually it's around 50, getting better when im flying and there are less cities around - may go higher than 60, like 90-120. But, some people say they having 50+ fps on ultra high. Those maybe Radeon drivers, or my luck
- Bad synchronization with Steam - overlay doesn't work randomly or it doesn't count hours of playing (5 hours instead of 50)
-Haven't noticed any gamebreaking bugs yet.

Hope my review was useful, sorry for some misspells

reviewText:
One of the very few sims out there, and a great one at that.
Insanely detailed, accurate flight and systems modelling, you'll feel like you're flying the real thing.
Of note is the Helicopter flight dynamics, which are currently unmatched in their realism.

More and more planes are being added, but as of June 11th, 2015, available planes ( each purchased separately, apart from the TF-51D and the Su-25T, which are free with the game ) :
_A-10 A Warthog

_Su-33 Sea Flanker

reviewText:
The most realistic Modern Fighter Flight Simulator you can find on the market, DCS World is free and it comes with some default planes, a mission editor + a few premade missions,  you can buy more planes, helicopters and features as DLCs.

All planes and helicopters are accurately simulated with amazing detail and true to life flight dynamics and weapons.

This simulator is really fun to play, Multiplayer gameplay offers the best possible experience and despite what some people say, the game is playable with mouse and keyboard, joystick is not needed to play.

Cons:

poor game optimization, random stutters and freezes

An unknown bug in multiplayer sometimes causes targets to be impossible to hit due to targets warping around making radar lose lock, in short range it can causes target to be invisible - probably caused by bad connection of some  players

Graphics are not the top

Pros:

Realistic Flight Simulator

Multiplayer in this game is awesome

reviewText: It's the best flight sim in the world. There simply is no substitute for CAS aircraft simulation. Falcon BMS provides a great F16 simulator. However, for everything else DCS is superior in every way. The A10C is the most faithfully recreated aircraft in their line up. But you can still have a great time flying the Russian black shark. The feeling you get when you successfully start an aircraft from a cold start is amazing. You also get to try out the SU25 for free (and the modern version for a price). it's not nearly as fun as the A10C, but it still lets you learn the basic weapon systems. It's VERY IMPORTANT to remember that the A10 is NOT the same as the A10C. the A10 will get you a more forgiving arcadey" aircraft (but still more realistic then something like say ace combat or battlefield
date: think of the old Jane's flight sims level). the A10C will give you the real deal. The A10C package does include basic tutorials for things like learning how to properly fly/start/land/engage in an A10. But things like working with JTAC will not be explained. So quite a bit of reading is required on your part."

reviewText:
This is a definite buy/download if you can invest some time and like complex games or simulations (or blowing stuff up). I was quite sceptic at the beginning but I still had my old joystick here and I thought: hey, it's free so let's try it. Flight simulators were always an alien genre to me but now I can't get enough. I bought the A-10C addition shortly after that, and was overwhelmed by its complexity (vanilla was already quite good).
Do not expect to lift off in less than 10 minutes. There is so much to do that you basically need to switch to the manual for every button or switch. Sometimes the manual isn't enough so you search the forums for useful information and somehow you end up reading military documents about the maths behind escaping a missile. At least 50% of my time with this game included doing research about some specific systems and I haven't even tried them all and don't even fully understand those which I use frequently. But you know what? I have been playing this game straight for a week, my sleeping cycle is deeply disturbed (I go to sleep at 5 A.M and get up at 9 or 12) because it is so addicting. I also tried the included mission editor and it seems to have a whole lot of potential.

There are a few downsides however: the campaign may feel quite realistic with much action going on, but it is missing some kind of story. Even though it is not as bad as  ARMA communications, the voices feel a bit robotic and monotone. I wish the AI would do some smalltalk even if it is maybe not appropriate.
Another point is the map: it is huge, for sure, but after a while it becomes a bit boring. Not that it matters much, but I like looking out of the window when flying to the combat zone. However, along with the new EDGE engine, ED will bring out a new map afaik.
I had a few performance issues during huge bomb dropoffs (dropping my entire payload) but all in all, it performs excellently for having so many units running at once.
Also you need to be very, very patient. For example the navigation system on the A-10C needs around 4 minutes to start up and you really shouldn't move the vehicle until it is done. My best time from starting the game and taking off on the runway lies around 7 minutes and I repeat it for every single mission. And more often than not I get blown up before even dropping my first bomb. It can get quite frustrating.

In conclusion, this is one of the most hardcore simulations I have ever touched and I will be touching it for some more time. it is deeply addicting and will lead you into buying more stuff so you can fight better oder try out new things (maybe a HOTAS instead of that old joystick). For those who have played other flight sims, don't wait. This download is well worth your time and the Su-25T model is really easy to fly in comparison to the A-10C. It has a few flaws, but you can easily ignore them while still trying what that button does... hey let's just push i- WHAAAaaaaaaaaa......

I'd gladly give it a 9/10 and that one point missing is for taking my sleep

reviewText:
FSX gone military. You have to love flight, (which I do,) and you have to know the controls/general similarities among all aircraft (which I also know). This ain't War Thunder or IL2 Sturmovik or any of those types of games. This is a full-out sim.
I, as a frequent FSX pilot and aircraft enthusiast, love this game. But, on the other hand, if you're one of those guys who wants to hop in a cockpit with all of the systems already running and not worrying about how to find the flaps switches, then DO. NOT. GET. THIS. GAME. Get War Thunder instead. It's still fun. Trust me. I play it.
Let's focus on the main point. This game is absolutely free. Yes, I know, only two free aircraft. But they're incredibly realistic, plus it's not like real military pilots switch from aircraft to aircraft, just as I love flying the Boeing 737-800 in FSX. It's the plane I fly the most, and the same logic goes for this game. You get involved in one aircraft, you learn about it, you cry over the lost hours of your life spent learning how to fly it, and then you love it. You don't go 5 minutes into an SU-25 and then decide meh. I'm more in the mood for flying a MiG. Maybe after that I'll also fly a Mustang."
To sum it up
recommended: and it's either you love it or you hate it."
