reviewText: This game is one of the best free to plays I have ever played. Its the kind of game that you can play for hours and still not learn everything there is. I have played 26 hours at the time of this review and still haven't used the autopilot, weapon systems, and much more. Everytime I play this I seem to learn something I didn't know before. It does take a while to get a hang of and I wouldn't recommend it to anybody who gives up easily because you do need to crash a lot in order to get a hang of everything. It is a game that seems to reward those who put in the time to learn how to fly specific planes because it has a ton of keyboard bindings, some a necessity some a conveniance. The planes you get in the free version do a good job at showing two sides of piloting. The TF-51D is a plane that in the game requires some learning in order to know how to just start it since it has an eight step proccess to start the engine. Once you get the TF-51D in the air it seems to be an easy plane to learn because it doesn't have a very high top speed and therefore has less you can mess up with in things such as landing. The SU-25T is completely different because it makes everything on the ground easy but once you are in the air you can break your wings off if you turn too sharp (which I know from experience). The community from what I have experienced is very friendly and I don't hesitate to ask them questions because they are helpful for the most part, aside from the LCtrl+e+e+e jokes every once in a while. Overall this game is great, it is a game I would willingly buy which makes it even better that it is free. If you would like a game that can teach you something while you learn, this would be a great game to try.

reviewText: The two free aircraft that you get are very fun to fly, and decent to introduce the game to you. This is a combat flight simulator with a command element to give the ground units more realism. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in aviation, or flying aircraft. This game does have a slightly steep learning curve, but that is countered by video tutorials available at the main menu of the game. I highly recommend that you visit the developers website, and download a copy of the checklist for the aircraft that you wish to fly. Then print it out and keep it handy, or download it to a tablet. The graphics are not bad for a flight simulator, but are not cutting edge. The multiplayer is not bad, but depends on the server and its mission. Most multiplayer missions are community developed, and not all aircraft are available in every mission. Their is also no in game VoIP feature, so downloading Teamspeak is a must for voice communication. All and all a good game, but better if you pick it up during a sale.

reviewText: Pre the 1.5 beta release, I thought the gameplay was brilliant but the graphics let it down. The mere fact that it was free didn't entice me to play the game even though I had bought A10c, I thought the visuals were very drab. However since the 1.5 beta update, I have bought the A10-a, Su-27 and the F86 and would like to buy the Mi-8MTV2 helicopter. The 1.5 update brought very nice enhancements, no, I can't call it enhancements, a totally different graphical experience would be a better method of explaining it, to the table. I now look around the internet (YouTube is very helpful) for as much documentation as I can find regarding the models which are in the game as they are so realistic (the way a sim should be) the documentation supplied with the purchases unfortunately are not enough. Getting to know each aircraft model takes a while to master (which I haven't yet) is my only negative thingy here apart from the fact that some of the models can be upwards of $60 Australian (as of 23rd Nov. 2015), so choose carefully which craft you would like to master.

reviewText:
Preface: I'm experienced on flight sims, but I'm also a normal person, with no $1000 setups, no endless hours and neurons to waste, nor a fixation on any single title or genre.
I played DCS probably a couple hundred hours or more in his non-steam releases especially A10C (the hours counter is bugged anyway atm).

I recommend the free plane (su-25T) and the Flaming Cliffs DLC, as all planes in there use classic pc-friendly control scheme and are thus fairly easy to pick up for any average flight simmer. I'd rate the difficulty in Flaming Cliffs models at probably somewhat easier than original/vanilla Falcon4 (but the overall game environment is MUCH tougher).

Game is rough around the edges, it's doable with a fair amount of patience but you will have systematic crashes and various unexplained wtf" situations to figure out...
There will be a lot of key remapping and note-taking.

MP is full of well-designed scenarios and it's a good thing it's populated
date: given the absence of dynamic campaign in solo.\n\nI advise caution in delving into 'professional' models of modern platforms -like A10C
recommended: Mig21- nless you are *really* hardcore  (note: I thought I was).\nChoppers are fun and the avionics aren't too complex
hoursPlayed: even a Black Shark is full of strane russian trinkets but still eons easier than a cold war/modern era plane. Mostly choppers are hard to control well without a serious setup
voteText: require lots of patience because of the slowness and general tactics involved

reviewText:
Preface: I'm experienced on flight sims, but I'm also a normal person, with no $1000 setups, no endless hours and neurons to waste, nor a fixation on any single title or genre.
I played DCS probably a couple hundred hours or more in his non-steam releases especially A10C (the hours counter is bugged anyway atm).

I recommend the free plane (su-25T) and the Flaming Cliffs DLC, as all planes in there use classic pc-friendly control scheme and are thus fairly easy to pick up for any average flight simmer. I'd rate the difficulty in Flaming Cliffs models at probably somewhat easier than original/vanilla Falcon4 (but the overall game environment is MUCH tougher).

Game is rough around the edges, it's doable with a fair amount of patience but you will have systematic crashes and various unexplained wtf" situations to figure out...
There will be a lot of key remapping and note-taking.

MP is full of well-designed scenarios and it's a good thing it's populated
date: given the absence of dynamic campaign in solo.\n\nI advise caution in delving into 'professional' models of modern platforms -like A10C
recommended: Mig21- nless you are *really* hardcore  (note: I thought I was).\nChoppers are fun and the avionics aren't too complex
hoursPlayed: even a Black Shark is full of strane russian trinkets but still eons easier than a cold war/modern era plane. Mostly choppers are hard to control well without a serious setup
voteText: require lots of patience because of the slowness and general tactics involved
helpfulPercent: and die far too easily
votesHelpful: so you might still have fun but not be very effective.\n\nOverall I feel like saying that planes with advanced avionics simulation like A10C are hardly worth the effort imho
votesTotal: in the sense that the intricacies of the electronic systems totally overshadow the 'game' aspect. If you really want to see the more advanced simulation you should start with the F86 or Mig15 maybe. Or as I said
votesFunny: best to forget it and go with the Flaming Cliffs models."

reviewText:
Review for v1.5...
I can only say...oh my God.... they did great job and game is so good that it's going to make me cry.


Review for version 1.2.xxx
This is the best flight simulator I played so far. Now add to that that it is combat flight simulator and your joy will never end.

My review is based on max realism settings, because true fly boys never play anything less than max hardcore.

Shortly:
- if you're looking for a game that will take you about 30 hours to master
- game where you will wonder if that's just too many keys to remember or are you just getting old
- game where before you even think of taking out an enemy you'll have to work out your approach, do the flyby and spot the ground targets first and try not to get taken out by SAM or AA guns in the process
- game that will put your flying skills and intelligence to the ultimate test
- game that will make your wife go insane from constant warning sounds
- game that you can really play by stick and not just pretend you need stick to play it
- you can very precisely tune entry level joysticks, so you don't get sudden and crazy reactions
- not to mention how happy it will make you that you can finally utilize some expensive hardware (it will make you wanna buy all hotas and flight controllers which exists.
- great game that is FREE?!
- game where all the time you waste in it will be so much better wasted than in Counter Strike


Look no further, you have it all in this game.

And did I mention it FREE?

P.S. try to snatch some DLC on sales just to reward the great team behind this game!

reviewText:
It is an amazing simulator, probably the best one out there. I bought the Flaming Cliffs 3 Addon so far and it is tons of joy, it is quite a bit challenging to learn the ropes if you are new to simulators (like I am) but once you get into it, you'll have a lot of fun.
Russian and American planes both have different avionics, making them feel different (and as such you have to learn to use both separately). Still trying to get used to the radar, but locking on and firing with missiles is piece of cake once you learn how to (watching the tutorials for both russians and americans twice did the trick for me).
So, all in all, if you are looking for a very realistic simulator, definitely give this one a shot because the basic game is free and has the Su-25 and the TF-51 in it, which by themselves already offer a lot of fun, and from there you can decide whether you want to get into the game more.
P.S. If you ever see me in a multiplayer game (I still have yet to play it), go easy on me. I'll most likely be an easy target for you anyways :P

reviewText:
DCS World is the best Combat Flight and Armored Simulator on the market, you really cannot find anything else better, especially for the price.
I fly Lockheed Martin's Prepar3D, which is a professional flight simulator, but the Combat is unlocked for $700 and is really only intended for the Military.  DCS World is as good as Prepar3D and the combat already unlocked.  If you fly professional simulators, you know detailed simulated aircraft can be usually $40-150+, so this is much cheaper.  On sale, it is an absolute steal.
Combined Arms alone for $5.99 is worth it because you're getting the best tank and armored simulator you'll ever find, period.
The UH-1 Huey is the only one I've seen with such detail and you would normally pay close to $80 for something like that for Microsoft FSX, Prepar3D or X-Plane.  So, for sale price of $15, its another steal!
If you ever wanted to try a Flight Simulator, this is the one for you because the tutorials give a much lower learning curve.

reviewText:
For those who do not want to read an essay here, I have three valid point for people who could be interested in this simulation game.

1. It's free to try.
2. It's the best war plane simulator out at the moment as my feelings go.
3. Each DLC" is a whole game on it's own. It's not only added content in the manner of new plane
date:
but it is intended as full game with campaing. All this is then integrated in one world for Multiplayer purposes.

And now for those whou would want to read a bit more. :)

It's so damn complex it blows my mind. It simulates the whole plane
recommended: each part of the machine is simulated in some form. It depends on what dlc you buy but for example the A-10C or KA-50 (and others too) have fully clickable cockpits and simulated on board computers. You can do everything a real pilot could do. With combination of really powefull mission editor anything is possible.\n\nYou get whole campaings for selected planes and even in the free to play basic package you can run a campain with SU-25 plane. Now when you combine this with multiplayer and really superb community
hoursPlayed: you get a package that can keep you entertained for years. Mercenary mission with your friends or with you "clan" are only the top of the iceberg here.\n\nI have only one con here
voteText: the game is really demanding. You will NEED to have a 64bit machine and highend CPU/GPU to really enjoy high details. This will maybe be solved when a new engine will be released (it's planed for this year) but I wouldn't put high hopes for this. Its mainly focused on adding DX11 support."

reviewText:
DCS World is, quite simply, the combat flight simulator that I've been waiting for.

From the get-go there's one thing that I have to make absolutely clear:

*This simulator is FUN!

If you are an aircraft enthusiast and always had the dream to fly, then this is your best bet - that is, if you are not a real pilot or if becoming one is not an option. The only things you won't feel when you strap yourself into a DCS World cockpit, are the G-forces.
The instructional training missions are on-point and helpful, the missions challenging and fun, the learning curve steep and frustrating at times, the manuals as thick as a medical encyclopedia - but you know what, it's the package.

I remember the days when I played Jane's USNF 97 and Microsoft Combat Flight Simulator, which were games that I couldn't get enough of. DCS World has replaced them with the same amount of, or even more, fun.


Simply brilliant.

reviewText:
There'a a lot to say about this game. Look for the TL;DR at the end.

This is probably the best deal on Steam. You don't have to spend a dime and you get access to an increadiable game. It's a full blown simulator, so expect a decent learning curve, especially with the weapons and navigation systems, but the game comes with a full compliment of interactive tutorials. After a good Saturday of playing, I had a good handle on everything and could freely enjoy playing. Mastering those skills is something else entirely, but of course, part of the fun.

Re-playability, for me this is probably the most important part of any game and for me, this game offers a lot of replayability, if your willing to put in some work. The game comes with a handful of missions, but the Mission Edditor allows you to create your own custom missions and it's a POWERFUL tool. Create a vast and complex mission or even campaign or a simple scenario for you to practice your shooting skills. If your savy, you can even use Lua to write your own scripts and really add complexity.

You don't need additional hardware for this game, but a good flight-stick at the minimum will make the game a lot more fun. If you have some cash and want to get a HOTAS stick and throttle, that's probably the best way to go. I don't have one and don't plan on getting one and I'm quite happy with that. Certain actions take me a bit longer, because I have to hit CTL-ALT something.

TL;DR - If you're looking for a combat flight simulator, this is the best I know of. If you have some money to spend I highly recomend the A10-C add-on. Expect a decent learning curve with a high pay off. A lot of re-playability with the custom mission editor. Maybe get a flight stick.

10/10

reviewText:
Probably the best and most realistic flight simulator on the market today. And on top of that you get to blow stuff up! What else could you ask for?

-Modules I have tried out-

A-10C: Most thorough flight simulation I have ever flown. From what I can tell all of the flight systems, computers, and avionics are operated exactly how they would be in real life and also have the same advantages, faults, and limitations. That being said starting it up from a cold start is always rewarding (If you do not mess something up along the way) but also very braintwisting. I have a much higher level of respect for the pilots who fly them for not just smashing their heads into a pulp trying to get the plane started up. The flight dynamics are exceptional also, and it's intricate weapon systems are very fun to blow up Russian tanks with.

UH-1H Huey: I have flown hundreds of flight simulators, but they were all with fixed winged aircraft. I could not find a better way to learn the art of helicoptering from this jem. The Huey is a historical legend for it's service during the vietnam war among others, and its later civilian services that still continue to this day. It sure flys like a legend too, you will not find many complicated computer systems you have to spend days learning about in it. Starting it up is simply turning the right combination of knobs and switches. Flying it is not real challenge after spending enough time to get used to it. You will learn to hover it and land in the most obscure places possible. It's flight dynamics like any other DCS title is exceptional. From the basic increase in lift as the helicopter gains horizontal velocity to the more uncommon stalling. The developers really show pride in their work as many other aerodynamic effects are modelled in such as rotors breaking due to a high RPM and negative G environment. The weapon systems are really fun to mess around with, there is really not much to them apart from shooting a minigun in the direction of your enemies and watching the carnage.

Flaming Cliffs 3: A great module for the less experienced flight simmers or casual player. Instead of focusing on a single high quality aircraft the developers worked on a great variety of more mediocre modelled aircraft. There are no interactable cockpits here besides closing the canopy. Apart from that, the planes are still modelled well for the status quo of a flight simulation. The F-15 included however has a very well modelled aerodynamics system that blows all the others in this module out of the water. Even though this module is much lower quality than the other titles, it is still very fun. And lets face it, cheaper too for the amount of content and variety it has.

I would reccomend for more veteran flight simulators to stay away from this module as most of the planes are not very well modelled and some are just dumbed down versions of other aircraft in the simulation like the A-10A and SU-25.

The F-15 is the plane that makes the module worth it, and as it is now only 10$ I reccomend just buying that instead of paying $50 on Flaming cliffs 3. The only reason I got it was it was on sale and was the same price of the F-15 at the time, so it just made more sense to buy all of Flaming cliffs 3 instead of just one aircraft included in it that was the same price as it.

Free aircraft:

TF-51: The TF-51 is a real fun plane for aerobatics if that is your cup to tea. It has a pretty good flight model and has a fully clickable and interactable cockpit, its flight and internal systems are just as well modelled.

SU-25T: Although it is not exceptionally well modelled with the fact it does not have an interactable cockpit, the SU-25T is one of the most combat effective ground attack planes provided in the simulation. You will have plenty hours of free fun learning the plane's systems, flight characteristics and employing it's weapon systems successfully. A great plane to introduce new pilots or players to the simulation.

reviewText:
This is the most awesome thing in the world since Fire&Beer and whoever doesn't play this 24/7 has NEVER lived!

edit 23.12.2014; Been playing DCS:World now since 09/2012 and there hardly goes by a week I don't take time to fly for a few hours. Make no mistake, this is a flightsimulator at heart, no GAME. Even if there are planes with a very low learning curve, for the full 'DCS experience' you should read or watch the manual/tutorials.

There are planes/helis for casuals, hardcore flightsim-nerds and of course newbies.

If you want to fly the A-10C and still find new things to learn after two years (~600 pages manual) or a Su-25T where you can learn how to fly & kill stuff in a few minutes with a tutorial is completly up to you.

WW2 era is progressing at a quick pace, at the time of writing there are two very active WW2 dedicated servers with fun& sometimes realistic scenarios although the allys are quite a little outgunned at the current point with only the P-51D Mustang, but that will change very soon.

Don't expect any balancing to spare your feelings, if an engine is more powerful IRL it will be in DCS.

I own all the current released DCS modules and promise you every full DCS module + FC3 is worth the money. No starforce DRM, buggy patch or delay development can destroy the immense fun I got out of this. This sim is the next  best experience to flying a plane RL we can get on the civillian market right now. X-plane/FSX/P3D have just inferior flight models and I have yet so see anyone of those do a comfortable 6dof-friendly & clickable cockpit like in DCS.


Pro-Tip: You can fly the Su-25T & TF-51D for free! The latter is nearly exactly the same as the P-51D Mustang, only unarmed. With the Mustang you can really see what this Sim is about, Su-25T look what FC3 may be like.
Tip 2: MiG-21 for the awesome afterburner kicks, turn & burn my friend!
Tip 3: F-86F for awesome engine feels, that slow engine spooling is a beauty to fly and especially land.
Tip 4: A-10C, requires a good joystick (BUTTONZ!11) to play comfortably but may also be played with inferior joysticks if you work with lot's of modifiers. After you get the hang of this the only plane that is more rewarding might be the F-16 from Falcon BMS.

reviewText: I started playing this game back in November of 2003 when it was called Lock-On: Modern Air Combat and was released on PC-DVD by Ubisoft.  I continued with the Flaming Cliffs, and Flaming Cliffs 2 Expansions, and now finally in Steam as DCS World with all these wonderful modules (read: individual aircraft simulators).  Mind you, this is no arcade shoot-em-up style game:  this is a STUDY SIM.  And each module/DLC/airplane is a detailed flight simulator of that airplane.  You will spend hours just figuring out how to start the plane, taxi, take-off; let alone navigate and use the weapons systems.  You will also REQUIRE at a minimum, a joystick.  I'm using a CH Products Fighter Stick, Pro-Throttle, and Pro-pedals (which I highly recommend.)  These days a REAL flight sim game is hard to come by:  DCS  has filled the niche wonderfully and exceptionally with these simulators.  When the zombie apocalypse happens, you can jump from DCS to the real versions of these planes with no problems.

reviewText: I climb into the pilot seat of my Bell UH-1.  After following start up procedures and insuring everything is in working order I slowly raise the collective.  My bird starts to steadily lift off the ground though it wants to spin to the right.  I rudder till it is straightened out and continue to ascend, wobbly.  I leave the confines of the airfield I took off from and make my way to a nearby city, making long sweeping turns as I go.  This isn't so bad I think to myself.  I've seen videos of people trying to fly and hardly getting off the ground, I guess ArmA3's advanced flight model actually payed of!  After a flying around the city for a few minutes, turn my attention back to the airport.  Is that a C-130 I see?  Surely it is.  I have to go get a closer look.  I make a beeline for the airport, my instrument panel shaking violently as I proceed at dangerous speeds.  As I approach the plane, seeing that it is indeed a C-130, I spot a C-17.  I've got to check that out too, I pull back on my stick and to the left, lower the collective a bit and rudder into the most beautiful turn I've ever seen.  Across the flight line I spot a 707 chasis.  I wonder if that is a KC-135!  I take off in it's direction.  As I approach from the front I realise that I am going to have to make a near 180 in order see the rear of the aircraft to see if it is infact a KC-135.  I pull the stick hard to the right, but I was coming in too fast and forgot to correct my collective.  Panic sets in as I watch the altimeter rapidly tick lower and lower.  Now is not my time.  I hammer up on the collective and continue to bring the helicopter around.  An alarm goes off, I assume it to be alerting me to the rapidly approaching ground, no such luck.  The helicopter lurches upward at an alarming rate, the alarm doesn't stop.  Suddenly I hear a loud *CLUNK*  I think to my self, What the hell was that?"  I then realise that it suddenly got a lot quieter
date: the sound of blades cutting through the air no longer a constant droning.  Infact it isn't their at all.  Alarmed I look around and spot my blades hurdling through the air.  I quickly apologize to my stoic faced co-pilot
recommended: he seems to have resigned to our fate.  Nonetheless I punch at the controls to no avail.  In a short moment we slam into the tarmac
hoursPlayed: exploding in a fireball of glory behind the aircraft I was so eager to check out.  I never found out if it was a KC-135 or not.\n\n10/10"

reviewText:
If you're looking for one of the best military flight sims made to date, look no further.
The A-10c Warthog flight model and cockpit / controls is one of the most comprehensive and true to life models I've ever seen outside of MSFS. Coupled with some third party voice activation and a decent HOTAS joystick, you really can't go wrong with DCS and the A-10c DLC. The helicopter DLC (namely the Huey) from what I hear are also brain-numbingly well done.

Expect some reading! I ended up printing out the 700 pg manual, memorizing two different bands of radio channels, and of course teaching myself the startup and setup procedures. And I'm still learning! Some people call this the epitome of study-sims" but to me
date: that's like calling a good book the epitome of "wordy-books." Don't be silly.\n\nEven though the DLC packs I've gotten have added up to be the most expensive title in my library
hoursPlayed: I've gotten much more than I ever expected
voteText: with more to come having only really stretched my wings in the A-10c. Certainly not purchases I regret. But not a flight-sim for those with a short attention span. Startup procedure is a solid 10 minute process. :)\n\nWith only a keyboard and mouse

reviewText:
GOOD GOD this is a challenging sim.. I have played it since it was LOMAC- and the changes and updates done make it feel like its all new all over again.. While not for the casual button mashing type, this sim rewards those who want to properly and correctly learn how to use and operate the complex modern weapons systems that are on modern combat aircraft.  The DLC addon planes are  a bit expensive for what you get IMO, but at sale price are worth it..

FC3 is def the best bang for your buck, with all the content that is included.

DO NOT jump into this and instantly expect to be successful.. it takes practice. My only real complaint about the game  itself is the lack of training missions. In LOMAC there were videos and play along missions that taught you what and how to use the systems. In DCS world its a video. Your best bet is looking online for training and tips.

reviewText: This is amazing in the Oculus DK2. The sense of depth, volume, and danger is like no other flight sim I've ever flown. At the time of this review, the DK2 isn't natively supported and it's a bit of a kludge to get it to work, but it is extremely immersive in the Rift. Roll back the canopy and lean outside the cockpit, look forward past that cowling with the pipes all popping, and then push the throttle forward for takeoff and it's like you are really there. Try this in a DK2 and you won't regret it!

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This is THE BEST combat sim I've ever played. The realism is outstanding and it's fun to play over and over. The amount of variables that can be controlled is almost overwhelming at first, but in a good way. The whole setup allows for a whole lot of freedom to plan an attack or a counter attack or to pretty much fight the enemy anyway you want. I really can't wait to see what they have coming in the future. It's hard to find a game that I truly get excited about these days but this is definitely one of them. They even have aerial refueling. Man is it hard but that's part of the fun. The only issue I have, and it's not really about the game design itself, is that I wish there were more American combat aircraft. I hope it's in the works but I'd really like to fly an AH-64 on a sortie in the Middle East or fly an F-22 and bomb the crap out of ISIS. There really is almost an unlimited amount of expansion as the creators didn't box themselves in with this game. The game is totally outstanding, even for Russians. :) :) (BTW that's why there are so many Russian aircraft)

reviewText: Not for people that think they can just hop in and fly like an ace. This is a simulator, not a arcade game like Ace Combat. There are settings in Dcs that make it alot like Ace Combat or War Thunder, but if you want to play this game right, you play it like it is ment to. I have yet to learn the systems of the aircraft I have (Flaming Cliffs 3) so I still have a little waise to go before im ready for intense combat. Here is a small list of some of the aircraft that will be added to Dcs in the coming months: F-18 Hornet, F-18 Super Hornet, P-47 Thunderbolt, Spitfire Mk9, F-14A/B Tomcat, L-39, and others. EDGE and Dcs World 2 should be here at any time, my guess is anywhere from the end of this month (March), to April. But thats just my guess, so take it lightly. With EDGE, Dcs will be even better with some sweet new graphics. New maps will also be added overtime aswell. So overall this is a great sim for those that love militery aviation, I myself am using it to train" myself in some of the basics of flight and flight in combat

reviewText: I have played Lock-on and Flaming Cliffs years ago, now we have DCS World and more aircrafts to fly with more coming. You really have to know how to fly and navigate or this is not the Combat SIM for you. Others who compare this to ARMA3 or other arcade games need to get a life. This is a Combat Sim not a XboX Controller game. There is very steep learning curve and you really need to RTFM and do the Training missons to know how to use everything in the aircraft. I fly the A-10C, KA-50, and Huey alot. I do have many years of Flight Sim experience so flying them is no issue with me. I do recommend this to any Combat Simmer that has had real flight sim flying and or is a real pilot looking for Sim combat fun.

reviewText: If you are keen on flight sims then DCS World is a must have.  I'm interested in WW2 aviation and enjoy the DCS experience.  If you are new to flight sims and want to try a propellor" sim I would recommend "il2 Battle of Stalingrad" before trying DCS.  DCS would probably be too over-whelming for the first time flight sim player.  BOS would give a more satisfying experience.\nBut for the flight sim grognard there is a lot to like about DCS.  Fully clickable cockpits
recommended: competitive AI and the option of jets.  Plus DCS WW2 is coming soon.\nGood support on the DCS forums."

reviewText: Bellissimo simulatore.\nPreso da poco, con DLC Su-27, dopo avere giocato con l'unico aereo disponibile nella versione free, forse la prima volta era ancora più spartano come simulatore, insomma non era preciso come adesso dopo gli ultimi aggiornamenti, ora sembra più reale, gli effetti G, le armi sono prefettamente simulati, dipende da come si imposta il simulatore dalle opzioni di gioco, la grafica risulta più dettagliata e più fluida, insomma fa più FPS di prima, ora e molto più giocabile, nella prima versione la grafica era un mattone, metteva in difficoltà pure una HD 7950 all'epoca, ora gira benissimo con dettagli al massimo su una R9 280X equivalente di una vecchia HD 7970 Ati, essendo un simulatore richiede una buona CPU minimo un quad core 4 GHz e 8 giga di ram, AMD o Intel.

reviewText:
The best military flight simulator out there. But as many negative reviews show: this is not a game. It is a study sim with some gameplay elements on top.

I started playing a few weeks ago and I greatly enjoy it.

You will enjoy DCS World if:

- you want to learn about aviation and want to understand how real military aircraft work
- you enjoy reading 600+ page technical manuals, forums and wikipedia pages
- you enjoy spending hours watching tutorial videos on youtube
- you own a HOTAS, TrackIR and can memorize a lot of keyboard shortcuts
- you have a lot of spare time
- you enjoy steep learning curves

Personally I love the experience. I currently have about 40 hours of game time logged (and have spent at least twice as much time reading manuals and watching tutorials). Yet I feel that I still have so much more to learn. It is awesome.

I would definitely recommend DCS World (and especially the A-10C DLC) to people who know what they are getting themselves into.

If you are looking for a relaxing game where you can jump into an airplane and shoot things, better look somewhere else.

reviewText:
This game is really fun to play with some of the DLC's.
If you like simulation games, or realism shooters, that kind of stuff this is a game for you!
It has the most realistic simulation in flying fighter jets by far.
It also has this for helicopters and other vehicle's.
You will get emersed into the game and have a great time with friends.
It has some downside's like all games and for me they are:
If you do not know anything about planes or helicopters and stuff, don't buy it unless you want to learn, this game is alot about learning new things.
If you do not have a joystick, defenetly don't buy it, unless you are getting one, it's pretty much unplayable without a joystick. and i mean to get the full simulation you need atleast a joystick
It can get a little hard remembering all the keybindings, and you might need to print out some pre flight check manuals, or just startup manuals if you are new cause its a pain in the ♥♥♥ to alt+tab this game.
Overall its a really fun game and best flight simulator i've played so far.

reviewText:
This is a Sim not for those who simply want to jump in and fly arcade style.

On my computer I can only run it at MEDIUM settings and get arroung 17 - 20 FPS  it's playable but I've only played free flight and some of the training, so not sure how it would go with more happening.

My specs:
Windows 7 Home Premium (64bit)SP1
Intel Core i7-2670QMCPU @ 2.20GHz, 16GB Ram, Nvidia GTX 560M 2GB

I have a few bugs when I first try to load it up it tends to freeze running 'Task Manager' (CTRL ALT DEL) then going back into the game without closing it down seems to get things going.
I have no idea why that works.

There is a very large learning curve involved here with so many keyborad combinations and my old Microsoft Sidewinder joystick really is not up to the task, if you are serious about this sim you will need a decent joystick to fly with.

Personally I enjoy games that are much simpler to fly IE Wings Of Prey but that is just me.

I can see there is a lot of entertainment to be had with DCS,  especially if you team up with some friends.

In conlusion.  Yes it's a great game. Lots to remember, decent computer to play a full graphics.

Will I play it? Most likely not. To much else around offering the simpler game play I enjoy.

reviewText: This game follows a steep learning curve. Seriously, it can take hours before you can even get your a-10 off the ground and hours more to land the plane properly; hours to learn the on-board computers and hours more to learn how to use the a-10.\n\nIf you're prepared to take on the monumental task of learning all the steps and procedures, by all means try this product out. But dont be suprised if you become frustrated, this is as close we can get to the real thing.

That was my past review I thought well now Ive gotten the gyst of it let re-review it. inb4 long ♥♥♥ read hope it helps

Firstly you do not need to have a HOTAS Joystick and Throttle or rudder pedals, its a bit more difficult but its still do able. The First im gonna say 50+ Hours I played with my Logitech Extreme 3D Pro $40 Joystick (I live in Australia), I played Su-25T, FC3 and Partially A-10C. I played them all comfortably the only thing that was needed was to remember more keybindings etc for the A-10c and Su-25T, FC3 all the important stuff was able to be bound to my joystick regardless the point is, for a free simulator that has a amazing engine and crazy realism to it all you need is $40 for a joystick and any extra money for modules and you can play. I bought the HOTAS Warthog around 60 hours into the game still dont have rudder pedals but thats fine I just use the 'Z' and 'X' keys thats it, if you love Military aircraft and you plan on enlisting one day then install this game, do it you wont regret it, if you love a challenge this is the game for you. To lay it out ill put some pros and cons below.


Pros:
- The SU-25T and PF-51 Mustang are Free
- The best Military Aviation Simulator on the market
- Aircraft are being added all the time for example Leatherneck Sims is working on a F-14 Tomcat model which is gonna be amazing
- All eras of Aircraft from 40's all the way to current.
- FC3 is more of a easier version but still in relation to the realism flight.
- Plenty of Single Player missions and servers to play on.
- Graphics are beautiful on this game as well as the sound.
- Performance is good even in MP, I have a 8 year old GPU and a Quad core CPU and with come custom settings and Mirrors off I get in SP 40-60 FPS and in MP 30-40 FPS
- If you buy it from the website or steam you can still play with eachother

Cons:
- It has a big learning curve
- There are only a few tutorial missions for standalone modules, there is no Tutorials on FC3, F-86F, Hawk only to name a few.
- SP missions do tend to bug out sometimes not all the time
- In the same sense that it is cheap it is also expensive with each module going for about $40+
- not all of the modules are on Steam, the ones on the DCS website are available on there for a while before it gets released on Steam. For example 14 out of the 17 available modules are available on Steam not including terrains or campaigns.
- You need Rudder pedals for rotary aircraft I tried and wasn't able to fly without them

So in short this is a great simulator it has its cons but its so worth it for the pros of the game. Some advice if you are thinking about spending $500 on a HOTAS Warthog, ask your self this are you going to make Simming a hobby or is it going to sit on your desk and collect dust? Simming is a expensive hobby so unless your going to use it dont bother. If you want to try the game out use a cheap joystick like the 3D Pro, if you are going to play moderately grab yourself a X55 Rhino it has HOTAS Functionality and so I have heard its a good joystick, if you know you are going to sim a fair bit at least 3-4 times a week and put hours into the game get the HOTAS Warthog and some rudderpedals. Also if you see the modules F-15C, SU-27, SU-25 and A-10A for DCS dont bother they are $10 each they are all included in Flamming Cliffs 3 Module as well as the MIG-29A, MIG-29S and SU-33.

So do I recommend the game to everyone? Yes give it a try you may like it
For aviation enthusiasts? Why haven't you already installed this
For people who want to make simming a hobby? Go buy a HOTAS and modules to your liking

I absolutely love this Simiulator and if you love Military Aircraft you will too, I hoped this long ♥♥♥ essay helped in your desicion.

reviewText:
Hugely detailed sim, can't stress it enough how much I'm in love with the DCS series of aircraft simulators thus far. The advanced flight model aircraft with fully functional cockpits are about as close to the real thing as you can get without actual military sim equipment. And ED along with other 3rd party devs are continually releasing new aircraft to build more possibilities for the game and it's multiplayer. And having this single platform bring all previous and upcoming sims into one environment is genius.

And the base platform comes with two free sims, a Su-25T (rivals A-10 Warthog with it's massive arsenal, it's powerful and easily capable to be able to hop right into multiplayer without spending a dime) and a trainer version of the P-51D, for aerobatic fun.

Note that this pretty much expects you to have a joystick, don't expect to play on a keyboard, unless you buy the Combined Arms pack that lets you take control of vehicles and fight it out on the ground.

Absolutely no reason not to give it a try. Unless you hate planes or something. But what kind of monstrous, awful person actually hates planes

reviewText:
Absolutely the best flight experience available on the PC.

Here are some considerations:

-It is a *simulator,* don't expect an arcade experience, even in the simple flight modes.
-Combat is very real, and therefore very difficult.  Success is very satisfying, but be willing to take the time to learn how to succeed.
-Despite some reviews the platform is exceptionally stable and functional, but the user interface is not intuitive (that's to be expected considering the scope of the simulation).  Again, it will take some time to learn.
-Multiplayer is super fun, but know that it's a session-based environment, not open world.
-Some modules (aircraft) will offer more content and detail than others, so do a little research before you purchase, and only purchase aircraft you are genuinely interested in flying.

If you're a fan of aviation simulations, patient, and willing to learn, you will thoroughly enjoy your experience with DCS world.

reviewText:
As a simulator, the fidelity is amazing. Everything is reconstituted in game from the tiniest details in the cockpit to the slightest nuances in aircraft behavior. Even compared to other simulators on the market, DCS is top-notch and possibly the only modern simulator to allow modern-day air-to-air combat in addition to a decent selection of older jets ranging from the skies of Vietnam, Korea and WWII.

Pros:
- Beautiful graphics
- Supremely realistic
- Good selection of aircraft
- Good selection of single player modes, campaigns, and settings
- Relatively healthy multiplayer

Cons:
- Somewhat hard to get into for beginners
- Not all aircraft have a tutorial section
- High cost of individual aircraft
- Modern air-superiority jets basically require TrackIR or equivalent to efficiently operate the off-bore sights

reviewText:
I am not an expert on flight simulators by any stretch of the imagination, so fair warning, I may be naive or ignorant in my assessment of this game.

That said, by far I believe DCS World, and what I have seen of its addons including DCS: A-10C Warthog, to be the most comprehensive and realistic modern combat flight simulator series I have ever seen. Many thanks to the developers for making the base game available for free on Steam. There's a lot included in DCS World to appeal to both the hardcore flight simulation crowd and to educators.

There are some minor omissions and simplifications from DCS World's default aircraft model, the Su-25, compared to its DLC packages in terms of the compexity of the cockpit's controls and graphical complexity, but what is available is so impressive to me I can't complain. Even this simplified model is more complex than many flight sims I've experienced in the past.

It's a good sign that some of the original companies which designed aircraft featured in this series are assisting with the development of the game/simulator, alongside the usual industry veterans. The sound design, user interface design, controls, mission editor and scripting system all seem to be quite well-executed. The game supports flightsticks, HOTAS and TrackIR, as well as (a rather inappropriate method of control in my opinion) the Microsoft Xbox 360 Controller alongside a mouse and keyboard.

I've not yet completely explored what the game has to offer in terms of difficulty levels, or rather, aircraft simulation settings, but my advice is that people who are looking for a casual, pick-up-and-go flight simulator should do their research or probably look elsewhere, as the game may be far more complex than expected.

That said, you can't beat the price, so I would insist that you test the game out and see what you think of it first. There's plenty of tutorials in-game as well as available on the Internet to help you become accustomed to the Su-25's basic startup/taxi/takeoff/landing procedures and usage in combat.

If you are interested in online multiplayer, there is a thriving community of DCS World players online these days. I bet there's a wingman available to help you out.

Overall, at a first impression I consider DCS World and its expansions to be an excellent value for its cost. I look forward to buying the expansions.

reviewText: I have never in my life been as challenged in playing a game as i have in this one. At times it feels like you can't do something or that a city is simply too well defended by SAMs. And just when you feel as though you are defeated and can no longer complete your mission, you decide to ask for some help. and everyone is extremely helpful. It doesnt matter if you are a vet or a new pilot people always help out and (almost) never put others down. I love this game with a passion. The fact that the aircraft are 1:1 replicas including flight models is amazing! There is a plane for every job and no 1 plane can do it all, it truly is a team effort to win. I give this game a solid 10/10!

reviewText:
DCS has a steep learning curve, however the large international community behind it fills the void with tutorials, campaigns guides. Eagle Dynamics have continued to lead the way in Flight Simulators in the void left behind by Microsoft and Jane's, with DCS World providing different Planes, Helicopters and Strategy modules through affordable DLC with Campaign and Mission Editors to prolong gameplay.

While the Visuals are impressive and the controls are reasonable quick to grasp, the game is very unforgiving. Many hours need to be put in to master combat flight, as quite often new players to Eagle Dynamics' games will be destroyed by the AI before they can even see them. This can lead players to become frustrated, so I do recommend those who wish to play this game watch some tutorials and practice against Harmless targets before trying against Hostiles.

I do recommend this game, but I have to admit I got very frustrated with Air to Air combat, so Air to Ground will prove less challenging for newcomers.

6.5/10

reviewText: A truly evolving combat flight simulation. The platform started as Lock on: modern air combat in 2003. Since then, the developer decided to part ways with Ubisoft and successfully made a niche for themselves. DCS world is the World of tanks" for modern flight simulation. Its still in its infancy with the scope. Things are constantly being updated/added and it has become a premier flight simulation. The graphics engine is dated with more CPU intensive processes
date: but the engine is due for a change with a revolutionary new EDGE (Eagle Dynamics Graphic Engine) that should be released this year.\n\nThe planes are represented in painstaking detail. The physics for each plane is the most accurate representation in any flight simulation
recommended:
including military trainers.

The base game is free and allows you to fly the Su-25T and TF-51D. But the others can be purchased through addons. There are two lines of DCS addons:

DCS: xxxx  :: Fully detailed aircraft including clickable cockpits. You need to spend 3-5 min just starting up the aircraft. Just like pilots in real life.

DCS: xxxx Flaming cliffs :: A study simulation. There are easy one button presses to get the systems/avionics going
hoursPlayed: but the aircraft physics is still modelled very much like the DCS counterparts.\n\nAt the end of the day

dated graphics etc.. but things are improving with every version.

reviewText:
DCS world is a great sim. However it does have a huge learning curve, for those who like the hard core sim where every buttion and switch is modeled in the aircraft look no further! lucky for people who aren't so hard core there is the Flaming cliffs 3 module although this module still takes a bit to figure out how to use the planes some you tube vids and some button mapping to a good quality joystick and dogfighting is a blast! FC3 adds the f15C, su-27, these planes are pretty easy to fly (you dont have to pull 20 switches to fire a cannon).

After playing a bit in FC3 and finally getting the hang of radar and beyond vis fighting I found DCS FC3 to be and enjoyable and challanging sim, dodging Heat seekers by dropping flares and pulling hard 7-9G turns only to have the missile pass beneath the belly of the aircraft by a factor of meters is such a rush, and then winning your first airvictory and then your first combat sortie is somthing that instills a sort of pride in you.

TL;DR: DCS world modules like A-10C,BLACK SHARK 2, and other stand alone planes are more suited to the hard core players (even though there is a game mode it's not very well explained) FC3 with a small amount of learning can be a rewarding and fun module for the Sim junkie.

(ps look up youtube tutorials as they tend to explain how to use the systems better i found this one helped alot with the F-15 http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=koa4MRGj41M however don't try to learn it all at once, you won't reamember and become frustrated!)

reviewText:
This is without a doubt the best combat sim on the entire market!

DCS World is not a game, its a heavy combat flight simulator with an extremely steep learning curve which definately takes a lot of time to fully understand and learn (I have had this game for over a year and I still count myself as a noob!)

If you really want to get the most out of this sim, you will need extra equipment like a HOTAS(Hands On Throttle And Stick) Joystick and throttle, preferably a reasonable computer with a good graphics card and TrackIR also helps but is not completely necessary.

By all means this sim is NOT finished, so expect a few minor bugs, but this does not take away any of the fun what so ever and you shouldn't let these bug scare you away from the sim because Eagle Dynamics are constantly working on it and the bugs are always being fixed. For example if you play this game through Steam, it only records your game time whilst you are in the main menu.

In my opinion to get the full experience from DCS World, you should definately start looking into buying some of the DLC, they may look expensive but there are regular sales which can discount up to 75%!

Eagle Dynamics are constantly adding new highly detailed aircraft and are hopefully going to be releasing DCS World 2 sometime soon which will get a major graphics update, inproved flight models and much more!

At least give DCS World a try or play/watch tutorials for the aircraft that you would like to fly before disliking it, even if flight simulation is not your favourite type of genre, you may be suprised!

As I said at the start, DCS World is easily my favourite sim ever and I think its great!

reviewText: DCS: World is definitely an amazing simulator. It by far outclasses others due to excellent flight models, a multiplayer that makes sense, easy-to-learn mission editor, and a large amount of detail. Even Flaming Cliffs 3 aircraft have more detail than something like War Thunder.\n\nActually, DCS excels at detail; for instance, the A-10C. It is the epitome of PC-based simulators, with most if not all of the real plane's functionality and flight characteristics. Another example is the Ka-50, and really any of the rotorcraft. They basically are the best in their class, with the full range of aerodynamic effects you'd get from the real thing- retreating blade stall, translational lift, oh ♥♥♥♥ my blades just up and left me" (hopefully not IRL)
date: etc.\n\nAnother thing is Nevada Test and Training Range. It is a huge map; most of Nevada
recommended: in fact. Even some parts of California. The entire Las Vegas city and suburbs are present and amazing. Even though it's not out for steam yet (as of updating)

reviewText:
Okay two caveats that need to be addressed right off the bat:
1)This game that you are downloading is module-based. So all you get from the free download is the P-51 and Su-25. Fun, but not super content-rich,
2)Do not buy this game if you want to jump in a cockpit and go blastin'. You will be disappointed.

Aside from that, I love this game. I was a big Ace Combat fan as a kid and always wanted something more technically challenging. It did take me a few months to gain a firm grasp of the controls, mission editor and combat tactics, but if you want to pretend to be a real fighter pilot, this is the one. Who knew trapping on a carrier or just even successfully flying a CAP would be so fun? Tons of official (Nevada map coming next month) and user made content (lockonfiles) and a really fun mission editor. Where else can you attack a US Navy carrier group with an armada of Backfire bombers and simulate how that would really happen? Plus, the first time you spot a target, evade his missile in a cloud of flares, then bang a Sidewinder or R-73 up his tailpipe is just really something.

tl;dr- Its a bit of a serious game (DCS is to other combat flight sims what ArmA III is to most tactical shooters. Its hard to figure out), but the level of realism and authenticity is unmatched.

10/10 real (fake) pilots only

reviewText:
*Disclaimer-This is a simulator not a game so it is not War Thunder or comparible to war thunder unless you are talking about the fact that you can fly planes in this but that is about it*

100% recommended for anyone who wants to learn to be a pilot or just blow up ISIS with 100% realism with many steps you could help everyone blow up ISIS and save the world.

Step 1: Open up the tutorial for the SU-25T that comes with the game.
Step 2: Practice with missions to get better at this simulator.
Step 3: Find the TF-51D that comes with the game and find a tutorial on youtube to start it up, use this to get used to buttons in the aircraft.
Step 4: Become a real pilot.
Step 5: Blow up ISIS.
Step 6: Buy some DLC for the simulator and learn and have fun

Remember this is not War Thunder, dont expect to master this in 5 mins, I havent played much of this, only 0.9 hours at the time of me writing this but i am here to enjoy it.

Get the simulator cause its free and have a go, keep going untill you know how to play and do it with friends or play on servers. It is better playing with people!

reviewText: Ok where to begin, I am coming from a previous warthunder standpoint with near 300+ hours on there if you add the time before I had it on steam. This was a huge learning curve from the arcade and realistic battles of warthunder but it was made easier from my time with the older sims such as Apache vs Havoc, Commanche vs Hokum and Mig alley all really old games but sims nontheless. I love this game already, it has aircraft I really wanted to fly and although the graphics show their age it is a wonderful sim, A Joystick is a must in this game as well as TrackIr which I am jerryrigging up as we speak. Now for those who say you cannot get into combat easily or whine that it's too hard just do all the training missions twice, grab a friend and make a custom mission with low threats (watch a tutorial on how to make a mission it is easier when the buttons make sense) and fart around for a few hours. I personally went from being whaaaaat when I started to hey all this makes sense and now I can take out 80% of the things I fire at in under 4 hours of playing this game. As of right now I am waiting for funds to get Flaming cliffs due to the volume of aircraft it gives and then combined arms. So if you are looking at this game do give it a try the learning curve may be steep but I have had fun figuring it out. And if graphics are an issue for you check back in a few months because update 2.0 will be bringing graphics equal to Arma 3 which will make this thee best combat aviation (and ground forces in combined arms) sim out there all way round.

reviewText:
Disclaimer - non steam user, transitioned to Eagle Dynamics own version a long time ago.
Hours are far from correct.

I'm far from a stranger to flight sims and I have tried pretty much every sim worth checking out.
And I have to say that DCS outshines pretty much every competitor!
If you're a flight geek this pretty much is a must for you.

There's something with this game that speaks to me in so many ways.
From flying a CAP in the F-15 or the brand new Mirage 2000c, going in for a gun run with the Hog, hugging the ground with Huey or simply making a nice vfr in the L39.
Yes it's hard in the begining, yes it takes sometime to learn but the sense of accomplishment you get from this is hard to find anywhere else.

I can't express enough how good of an experience this game really is!

The only complaint I might have had with this game would have been the slightly dated graphics. But with the release of  (the FREE) DCS 2 that complaint is gone.

reviewText:
If you want to feel like a real pilot, but you financialy or phisically  can't afford to be a pilot in real life, than this is the game for you.

Years ago I played Lock On - Mondern Air Combat and one day I thought, wouldn't it be awesome if there would be a game with these awesome grapics and realism and they made the cockpit fully clickable like in Falcon 4 Allied Force wich I played at the time too. They must have read my mind, because a couple of years later, this game showed up. Back then it was Black Shark (World and helo in one, later they sepperated everything).

This game is  awesome and relatively perfect. This comming from a man that would love to fly a jet in real life. DCS World is free and comes with one non fully clickable cockpit SU-25T. The rest of the modules, wich holds one fully clickable cockpit aircraft, you need to buy sepperately. This is kind of ideal. Why? Because you don't have to buy the airplanes that are incrdibly ugly to you. If there is an airplane you absolutely love, buy ther module. If there is an airplane you absolutely hate, let it be and don't buy the module.

What I don't like is that the modules are so expensive. And with expensive I mean that every module, wich means one airplane or one new map, are all priced like a full, brand new, well liked and antissipated game. wich menas 50-60 euro's. No Idea what it would be in Dollars. The airplane modules I can understand, but a map? Well, that is a bit much in my opinion.

However I do love the game very much. Beautifull graphics wich you don't see much in games. Super realistic aircraft where you have to use the cockpit buttons to set up weapons, navigation systems, radio's etc. This is the game for all of us who can never realize our dreams of becomming real pilots.

reviewText:
Love DCS. Unfortunately I don't have TrackIR or an Oculus Rift DK2 so I feel I'm missing out on a bit of the immersion. Logitech Wingman Extreme 3d Pro joystick does me but having to enable the joystick config file every single time I play is annoying.

Flaming Cliffs and what it does needs more of an explanation as I ended up buying F-15 AND flaming cliffs which was a waste. I've bought the enhanced versions of both A-10 and Blackshark 2 which are fantasticly authentic with cockpit buttons.

I would love to see more British aircraft and helicopters... in particular WWII aircraft like the Spitfire and Harrier.
Tornado and Jaguar ... and of course the AH-64 Apache Gunship which I'm told was scrapped as module because the team responsible were making the E variant which is currently still in service and classified... they were told to drop it.

I'd be happy with the D variant rather than a mod skin over the Blackshark 2 which doesn't really do it for me.

Waiting with baited breath for the Hawk module to drop in price on steam as I've paid enough and I'm not forking out another £25+ to fly a Hawk.

Can't wait for DCS2 and DX12 graphics. My pc is upgraded and ready to go for it.

reviewText: Simply put, it is an awesome simulator. I have the Hawk, Albatross, Sabre and F15C and I love them all. However, if you're not patient and don't know much about flying I would be a little careful about buying it. I personally urge you to read some books about flight or fly a real Cessna or just talk to a pilot before trying this out. Principles you learn from real life flight and books actually apply to this simulator. It does a fantastic job of rewarding people that do their homework and learn about their aircraft. It is not a simulator you can just jump into and expect yourself to be proficient at. It requires time and a lot of practice.\n\nThis simulator is meant for aviation enthusiasts, not gamers.

reviewText: DCS is not for those not willing to learn how to operate aircraft by the book. I currently have all but four of the modules for DCS and find the ammount of detail put into the systems of each aircraft amazing. I find it awesome that I can get into my MI-8 and start it up per the actual aircraft's checklist and then operate it like the real thing. The graphics are great, especially the aircraft textures, considering that the game is growing in age. Hopefully we will see the release of the new EDGE engine soon and the graphics will be back up to par. I highly recommend this simulator for flight enthusiasts, combat flight enthusiasts, or even casual gamers, because you can tweak the options to suit that style of play. It is however much more fun and more of a challenge to try and learn the systems when in full realism mode.

reviewText:
DCS is an amazing game if you have the patience and mental capacity to learn and remember all of the systems and how to use them on the specific aircraft that you want to fly, and once you do this, it'll be implanted into your mind and you'll have fun. If you want to get into air-to-air engagments, then go for the F-15C. If you want to get in to air-to-ground engagments, then go for the A-10A, but if you wan to fly a plane almost exactly as it is flown in real life, then go for the A-10C.

The main difference in modules like the A-10C and the F-15C (besides them being two completely different aircraft) is the interactive cockpit. This means that the A-10C has a cockpit with buttons that are almost all clickable and all carry out the same function as the real life counterpart. Other than that the modules all have the same realism level meaning that they handle and behave very realistically both in combat and free flight missions.

I give this game a 9.5/10 rating because you have a somewhat limited selection of planes to fly, but this isn't an immediate problem because by the time you learn how to utilize a plane's capabilities effectively in combat,  you won't want to instantly jump into another because you probably won't be interested in making yourself commit suicide.

Warning:
DCS is not a game, it's a simulator. You can't just load it up and play with no learning period. If you want a game like that, then play Ace Combat. This game is very serious, so don't think you'll be the one to just hop on and instantly be good at it, because if you do, you'll loose all confidence you had in yourself as a gamer.

reviewText:
Okay two caveats that need to be addressed right off the bat:
1)This game that you are downloading is module-based. So all you get from the free download is the P-51 and Su-25. Fun, but not super content-rich,
2)Do not buy this game if you want to jump in a cockpit and go blastin'. You will be disappointed.

Aside from that, I love this game. I was a big Ace Combat fan as a kid and always wanted something more technically challenging. It did take me a few months to gain a firm grasp of the controls, mission editor and combat tactics, but if you want to pretend to be a real fighter pilot, this is the one. Who knew trapping on a carrier or just even successfully flying a CAP would be so fun? Tons of official (Nevada map coming next month) and user made content (lockonfiles) and a really fun mission editor. Where else can you attack a US Navy carrier group with an armada of Backfire bombers and simulate how that would really happen? Plus, the first time you spot a target, evade his missile in a cloud of flares, then bang a Sidewinder or R-73 up his tailpipe is just really something.

tl;dr- Its a bit of a serious game (DCS is to other combat flight sims what ArmA III is to most tactical shooters. Its hard to figure out), but the level of realism and authenticity is unmatched.

10/10 real (fake) pilots only

reviewText:
This is without a doubt the best combat sim on the entire market!

DCS World is not a game, its a heavy combat flight simulator with an extremely steep learning curve which definately takes a lot of time to fully understand and learn (I have had this game for over a year and I still count myself as a noob!)

If you really want to get the most out of this sim, you will need extra equipment like a HOTAS(Hands On Throttle And Stick) Joystick and throttle, preferably a reasonable computer with a good graphics card and TrackIR also helps but is not completely necessary.

By all means this sim is NOT finished, so expect a few minor bugs, but this does not take away any of the fun what so ever and you shouldn't let these bug scare you away from the sim because Eagle Dynamics are constantly working on it and the bugs are always being fixed. For example if you play this game through Steam, it only records your game time whilst you are in the main menu.

In my opinion to get the full experience from DCS World, you should definately start looking into buying some of the DLC, they may look expensive but there are regular sales which can discount up to 75%!

Eagle Dynamics are constantly adding new highly detailed aircraft and are hopefully going to be releasing DCS World 2 sometime soon which will get a major graphics update, inproved flight models and much more!

At least give DCS World a try or play/watch tutorials for the aircraft that you would like to fly before disliking it, even if flight simulation is not your favourite type of genre, you may be suprised!

As I said at the start, DCS World is easily my favourite sim ever and I think its great!

reviewText: This game is a kind of simulation of airplanes. You are able to fly certain planes in a simulated environment in military missions. There are many planes available though most are extra dlc's, you only get the soviet SU-25T for free, which is still very fun to play. Generally you should have a joystick with thrust and use either TrackIR or something like FaceTrackNoIR to control your head movement in the cockpit. Also important to mention is that the different dlc's (also called modules) with their planes have different simulation difficulty, some have a non-clickable 3D cockpit with simplyfied flight model and some like the A-10C require you to basically learn how to start up and fly the plane in a way you would do in reality with all it's buttons, switches and so on. Overall it is a great game, not the most accesible but the free plane is great to explore whether you like this game and you can always decide to go more hardcore with other planes or difficult missions. Aaaaand you also get the free mission editor/campaign editor which allows you to create your own content.\nSo all summed up, you like flight simulation and fighting jets? Try this, it's nice.

reviewText:
Note: This review is for the Vive version.

Pros:
Free to play if you like the Mustang or Frogfoot
Tracks head movement well while looking ahead or to the sides
Detailed cockpits are neat

Cons:
Head tracking is extremely jerky from about 4 o'clock to 8 o'clock even on the lowest settings
Default head positioning is somewhere about three inches inside the headrest
All UI elements track to the head so things on the outer edges are virtually impossible to read, including instructions during the tutorials
For Vive owners at least, the detailed cockpits are basically eye candy, since there's absolutely no interactivity at all, meaning that to do anything you have to keep lifting up the headset to see the keyboard

Serious, Egregious Cons:
The game didn't respond well to keyboard input; I had to press each key combination between 10 and 15 times before it would acknowledge the input, assuming it responded at all.  Due to the nonresponsive keyboard, I wasn't even able to exit the game.  I eventually managed to force quit the game with some fancy mousing, and discovered that DCS had actually disabled my keyboard completely, which would explain why even Ctrl-Alt-Del wouldn't work.

From the reviews I've seen I'm sure DCS World is playable and possibly even enjoyable, but it certainly didn't give me the opportunity to experience that first-hand.

reviewText:
Home-Made Enchiladas

3 tablespoons vegetable oil
1 1/2 pounds skinless boneless chicken breast
Salt and pepper
2 teaspoons cumin powder
2 teaspoons garlic powder
1 teaspoon Mexican Spice Blend
1 red onion, chopped
2 cloves garlic, minced
1 cup frozen corn, thawed
5 canned whole green chiles, seeded and coarsely chopped
4 canned chipotle chiles, seeded and minced
1 (28-ounce) can stewed tomatoes
1/2 teaspoon all-purpose flour
16 corn tortillas
1 1/2 cups enchilada sauce, canned
1 cup shredded Cheddar and Jack cheeses
Garnish: chopped cilantro leaves, chopped scallions, sour cream, chopped tomatoes
Directions
Coat large saute pan with oil. Season chicken with salt and pepper. Brown chicken over medium heat, allow 7 minutes each side or until no longer pink. Sprinkle chicken with cumin, garlic powder and Mexican spices before turning. Remove chicken to a platter, allow to cool.

Saute onion and garlic in chicken drippings until tender. Add corn and chiles. Stir well to combine. Add canned tomatoes, saute 1 minute.

Pull chicken breasts apart by hand into shredded strips. Add shredded chicken to saute pan, combine with vegetables. Dust the mixture with flour to help set.

Microwave tortillas on high for 30 seconds. This softens them and makes them more pliable. Coat the bottom of 2 (13 by 9-inch) pans with a ladle of enchilada sauce. Using a large shallow bowl, dip each tortilla in enchilada sauce to lightly coat. Spoon 1/4 cup chicken mixture in each tortilla. Fold over filling, place 8 enchiladas in each pan with seam side down. Top with remaining enchilada sauce and cheese.

Bake for 15 minutes in a preheated 350 degree F oven until cheese melts. Garnish with cilantro, scallion, sour cream and chopped tomatoes before serving. Serve with Spanish rice and beans.

reviewText: This game is probably the most immersive, detailed flight simulator out there! The flight dynamic models are very accurate and simulate the real-life aircraft very well indeed. In my opinion, the A-10C Warthog Module is well worth the price, simulating all the instruments and flight controls (from the ejector seat to the climate control), providing an extremely detailed level of gameplay\n\nHowever, the game isn't very beginner friendly and takes a while to familiarize with the controls, keybinds and aircraft operation. The game can also consume performance at times. Despite this, DCS: World (providing the SU-25T and the TF-51D aircraft for free) is definitely worth the download, regardless of which modules you additionally purchase. In terms of simulation, this is the best of the best. 10/10

reviewText: I've never played a simulation game before. This one seemed very realistic from what I could tell (I've never flown a plane before). Me and my friend had a blast trying to learn this game. I found DCS World to be very entertaining and sometimes comical mostly because we were SO terrible at it. I do highly recommend it and one day want to come back to it, maybe if I get a joystick or just have more time. This is a game that definitely takes practice. There are dozens of control keys and combinations that you have to remember just to fly and land a plane, and another couple dozen for combat. That's like a memorization game in itself! Me and my friend joked that if we could successfully fly this plane then we could head over to the local airport and probably fly a real plane. Funny but the game is so detailed that it's most likely completely true!

reviewText: (You may notice that I have 0.0 hrs on record playing DCS world, that's because I play it through the Eagle Dynamics DCS world launcher.  I had that originally with some DLC before Steam offered it.)\n\nAs far as I know Digital Combat Systems is the only software company that is dedicated to making true to life simulations.  If your into flight simulators, and you love the military planes, this is a must have!  The DLC that you buy for this is well worth it.  These are not your run of the mill games, the learning curve is quite high.  But if you dedicate the time to learning the sims you will know what it feels like to be a combat pilot.  Hell it took me multiple nights of playing just to learn how to start up the A-10!  And you think that it's easy to take off in a P-51 Mustang, that's what I thought too until I went turning to the left on the runway smack dab into a building.  I didn't know that you need to compensate for P factor.  Hell, didn't know what P factor was until started playing this simulator.  What I'm trying to say is that when it comes to simulators for the PC, it don't get any closer to the real thing than it does with DCS simulators.

reviewText: This is the best modern flight simulator in the market right now. DCS World is seperated into two types of modules: 'DCS' level and 'Flaming Cliffs' level. DCS level aircraft such as the A-10C, the KA-50, and the UH-1 require an understanding of aircraft avionics to operate them. Most procedures are 80-90% accurate. Flaming Cliffs level modules have the the same quality of flight modeling, but they have simplified avionics. This means it requires a single button press to start the engines for example. I highly recommend this title if you have an interest in military aircraft simulations.

reviewText: Ok so the game looks good and it is indeed a flight sim. The first thing you need to ask yourself is 'Can you fly a SU25t frogfoot?' if the answere is no then don't worry because there is a tutorial in place with DCS world that talks you thru the take off and landing procedures etc. So now you need to ask your self 'can you fly any plane whatoever?' if the answere is still no then here begins your problem because there are no tutorials available in game except a few videos showing you whats what which are next to useless if you haven't ever flown for example an F15 eagle or a P51 mustang then you will need to do your own research on how to fly them. I started the A10 campaign and managed to take off as the engine was already running but once I did I found that I was just a piece of metal in the sky because I couldn't operate any of the systems to use my weapons and even if I could I didnt have the first clue about how to effectively use them anyway.\nSo why does this game get a 'thumbs up'? because it is a good creation so much effort has been put into this that it deserves nothing less, a 'thumbs down' would suggest a bad game which is unfair and I can imagine that when you take off in multiplayer with your buddy and fly in formation that this on it's own would be extremely satisfying let alone completing missions from the hangar to take off to battle and back to landing...I'm just totally incapable of learning how to fly an acutal plane without having actually gone to flight school first. This is a good game but requires a lot of work just to be able to do the basics.

reviewText:
The First Tutorial:

Tutorial Guy: Remember these hundreds of odd button combinations, then press this this this plus that.

Me: Okay..Engines on.

Tutorial Guy: Increase throttle and taxi to the runway.

Me: *Increases throttle too much flips plane over and blows up*

Take 2

Tutorial Guy: Good you made it to the runway now stay in the middle and take off with the controller.

Me: *Going really fast* HOW DO I TAKE OFF?! What button is the controller?!

Me: *Magically gets in the air, but continues going up and I'm not sure how to stop it*

Tutorial Guy: Good you made it to the air try flying around a bit.

Airpane: *BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP*

Me: What's happening?!

Tutorial Guy: Congratulations that concludes the first tutorial.

Airpane: *BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP*

Me: EJECT EJECT!

*Explosion*

11/10

reviewText:
Rating
'7.5/10'

Personal Thoughts
A great Simulator game by Dynamic Eagles.
Beautiful lookin' simulator.

From Simple Simulation to study level
Simulation, good and immersive.

I recommend this game with a TrackIR and a joystick.
I currently have TrackIR 5, no joystick. But I am
not a dog fighter pilot, so it's not a must must.

You can go in a simple simulation, and have the fun.
Or you can go hardcore, and learn the study level
simulations. This makes the game good for most people.

This is for steam only, the game will most likely never have
game breaking glitches, the standalone edition is more up
to date but you risk, game breaking glitches.

Extra Info
- I may not have many hours, but I preferrely
play the non-steam version, it's way more up
to date, and has exclusive standalone deals only.
